dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fantasy_television\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eGame of Thrones is an American fantasy drama\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Benioff\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003etelevision series created by David Benioff and\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D._B._Weiss\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eD. B. Weiss for HBO. It is an adaptation of A Song of\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Song_of_Ice_and_Fire\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eIce and Fire, a series of fantasy novels by\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_R._R._Martin\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eGeorge R. R. Martin, the first of which is\u003c/a\u003e \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Game_of_Thrones\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eA Game of\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Game_of_Thrones\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eThrones. The show premiered on HBO in the United\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\nStates on April 17, 2011, and concluded on May 19,\n2019, with 73 episodes broadcast over eight seasons.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westeros\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eSet on the fictional continents of Westeros and Essos,\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ensemble_cast\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eGame of Thrones has a large ensemble cast and follows\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Story_arc\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eseveral story arcs throughout the course of the show.\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iron_Throne_(A_Song_of_Ice_and_Fire)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eThe first major arc concerns the Iron Throne of the\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_of_A_Song_of_Ice_and_Fire#Seven_Kingdoms\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eSeven Kingdoms of Westeros through a web of\u003c/a\u003e\npolitical conflicts among the noble families either\nvying to claim the throne or fighting for independence\nfrom whoever sits on it. The second major arc focuses\non the last descendant of the realm's deposed ruling\ndynasty, who has been exiled to Essos and is plotting\nto return and reclaim the throne. The third follows the\nNight's Watch, a military order defending the realm\nagainst threats from beyond the Seven Kingdoms'\nnorthern border.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones attracted a record viewership on\u003c/em\u003e\nHBO and has a broad, active, and international fan\nbase. Many critics and publications have named the\nshow one of the greatest television series of all time.\nCritics have praised the series for its acting, complex\ncharacters, story, scope, and production values,\nalthough its frequent use of nudity and violence\n(including sexual violence) generated controversy. The\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_of_Thrones_season_8\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003efinal season received significant criticism for its\u003c/a\u003e\nreduced length and creative decisions, with many\nconsidering it a disappointing conclusion. The series\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primetime_Emmy_Awards\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ereceived 59 Primetime Emmy Awards, the most by a\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primetime_Emmy_Award_for_Outstanding_Drama_Series\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003edrama series, including Outstanding Drama Series in\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_awards_and_nominations_received_by_Game_of_Thrones\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e2015, 2016, 2018 and 2019. Its other awards and\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_awards_and_nominations_received_by_Game_of_Thrones\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003enominations include three Hugo The Wildlings living north of the Wall include Gilly (Hannah\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hannah_Murray\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eMurray) and the warriors Tormund Giantsbane (Kristofer Hivju) and Ygritte (Rose Leslie).[[13]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eyj y ( )\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roose_Bolton\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eBolton (Michael McElhatton), and Roose's illegitimate son, Ramsay Snow (Iwan Rheon). Robb accepts\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talisa_Maegyr\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ehelp from the healer Talisa Maegyr (Oona Chaplin), while elsewhere, Arya befriends blacksmith's\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gendry\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eapprentice Gendry (Joe Dempsie) and assassin Jaqen H'ghar (Tom Wlaschiha). In the Stormlands, the tall\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brienne_of_Tarth\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ewarrior Brienne of Tarth (Gwendoline Christie) is introduced to Catelyn.\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_of_A_Song_of_Ice_and_Fire#King's_Landing\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eIn King's Landing, Ned's best friend, King Robert I Baratheon (Mark Addy), shares a loveless political\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cersei_Lannister\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003emarriage with Cersei Lannister (Lena Headey). Her younger twin brother, Ser Jaime (Nikolaj Coster-\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nikolaj_Coster-Waldau\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eWaldau), serves on the Kingsguard while their younger brother Tyrion (Peter Dinklage) is attended by his\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shae_(character)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003emistress Shae (Sibel Kekilli) and mercenary Bronn (Jerome Flynn). Cersei's father is Tywin (Charles\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Dance\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eDance), head of House Lannister and the richest man in Westeros. Cersei has two sons: Joffrey (Jack\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jack_Gleeson\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eGleeson) and Tommen (Dean-Charles Chapman). Joffrey is guarded by the scar-faced warrior Sandor\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sandor_Clegane\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\"The Hound\" Clegane (Rory McCann).[[14]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petyr_Baelish\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eThe king's Small Council includes his treasurer, Petyr \"Littlefinger\" Baelish (Aidan Gillen), and his\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spymaster\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003espymaster, Varys (Conleth Hill). In Dragonstone, Robert's younger brother, Stannis (Stephen Dillane), is\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Melisandre\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eadvised by foreign priestess Melisandre (Carice van Houten) and former smuggler Ser Davos Seaworth\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liam_Cunningham\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e(Liam Cunningham). The Tyrell family from the Reach is represented at court by Margaery (Natalie\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natalie_Dormer\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eDormer). The High Sparrow (Jonathan Pryce) is given power as a religious leader, while, in Dorne, the\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ellaria_Sand\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ewarrior Ellaria Sand (Indira Varma) seeks vengeance against the Lannisters.[[13]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_of_A_Song_of_Ice_and_Fire#Free_Cities_and_vicinity\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eAcross the Narrow Sea in Pentos, siblings Viserys Targaryen (Harry Lloyd) and Daenerys Targaryen\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emilia_Clarke\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e(Emilia Clarke) (colloquially referred to as \"Dany\") are in exile, with the former plotting to reclaim his\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khal_Drogo\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003efather's throne. Daenerys is forced into marrying Khal Drogo (Jason Momoa), a leader of the nomadic\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_of_A_Song_of_Ice_and_Fire#Dothraki_Sea\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eDothraki. 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eBoth television critics and historians have praised the series for what was perceived as a sort of medieval\nrealism.[[15][16][17]] George R. R. Martin set out to make the story feel more like historical fiction than\ncontemporary fantasy, with less emphasis on magic and sorcery and more on battles, political intrigue,\nand the characters, believing that magic should be used moderately in the epic fantasy genre.[[18][19][20]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orc\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eMartin said, \"The true horrors of human history derive not from orcs and Dark Lords, but from\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neo-medievalism\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eourselves\".[[21]] Academics have classified the series as neo-medieval, which focuses on overlapping\u003c/a\u003e\nmedieval history and popular fantasy.[[22][23][24]] A common theme in the fantasy genre is the battle\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Good_and_evil\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ebetween good and evil, which Martin says does not mirror the real world.[[25]] In the series, political\u003c/a\u003e\nleaders have mostly been portrayed negatively, as they usually disregard the well-being of the common\npeople and are guided in their decisions by selfish reasons. Few possible exceptions include Daenerys\nTargaryen, Jon Snow and Tyrion Lannister, who have shown concern about the populace. Still, their\nmethods or commitment to the cause have been criticized.[[26]] Martin explores the relationship between\ngood and evil through the questions of redemption and character change.[[27]] Unlike in many other\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Narration#Narrative_point_of_view\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003efantasies, the series allows the audience to view different characters from their perspective.[[20][28]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIn early seasons, under the influence of the A Song of Ice and Fire books, main characters were regularly\nkilled off, and this was credited with developing tension among viewers.[[29]] Martin stated in an interview\nthat he wanted to depict war and violence in a realistic way, which sometimes mean the hero or main\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ej, p\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plot_armor\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003edeveloped \"plot armor\" to survive in unlikely circumstances and attributed this to\u003c/a\u003e \u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones\u003c/em\u003e\ndeviating from the novels to become more of a traditional television series.[[29]] In a 2012 study, out of 40\nrecent television drama shows, Game of Thrones ranked second in deaths per episode, averaging 14.[[31]] A\nscientific study conducted in 2018 stated that about 60% of the major characters died as a result of\nviolence and war.[[32]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eInspirations and 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAlthough the series's first season closely follows the events of the first novel, there were significant\nchanges made for later seasons. According to Benioff, the TV adaptation is \"about adapting the series as a\nwhole and following the map George laid out for us and hitting the major milestones, but not necessarily\neach of the stops along the way\".[[33]] Aspects of the novels' plots and their adaptations are based upon\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High_medieval\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003esettings, characters, and events in European history.[[34]] Most of Westeros is reminiscent of high medieval\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feudalism\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eEurope, from its geography and castles to its cultures, the feudal system, palace intrigues, and the knights'\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tournament_(medieval)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003etournaments.[[35][36]] Like medieval Europe, most of the houses in the series use the patriarchal system of\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gothic_fiction\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003epower.[[37]] The series also includes elements of gothic fiction, including torture tropes.[[38]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wars_of_the_Roses\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eA principal inspiration for the novels is the English Wars of the Roses (1455–1485) between the houses of\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/House_of_Lancaster\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eLancaster and York, reflected in Martin's houses of Lannister and Stark.[[39]] The scheming Cersei\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isabella_of_France\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eLannister evokes Isabella, the \"She-Wolf of France\" (1295–1358).[[34]] She and her family, as portrayed in\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maurice_Druon\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eMaurice Druon's historical novel series,\u003c/a\u003e \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Accursed_Kings\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eThe Accursed Kings, were a main inspiration of Martin's.[[40]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hadrian%27s_Wall\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eOther historical antecedents of series elements include: Hadrian's Wall (which becomes Martin's Wall),\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roman_Empire\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ethe Roman Empire and the legend of Atlantis (ancient Valyria and its Doom), Damascus steel (Valyrian\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Damascus_steel#Cultural_references_and_misconceptions\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eSteel), Byzantine Greek fire (\"wildfire\"), the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World (such as the Titan of\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_of_A_Song_of_Ice_and_Fire#Braavos\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eBraavos and Hightower of Oldtown), Icelandic sagas of the Viking Age (the Ironborn), the Mongol\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e( ) gyp ( y)\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_Renaissance\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eRenaissance.[[34]] The series's popularity has been attributed, in part, to Martin's skill at fusing these\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alternate_history\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eelements into a credible version of alternate history.[[34][41]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" Weiss and David Benioff\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIn January 2006, David Benioff had a telephone created the series, wrote most of its episodes\nconversation with Martin's literary agent about the and directed several.\nbooks he represented. Having been a fan of fantasy\nfiction when he was younger, he became interested in A\n\u003cem\u003eSong of Ice and Fire, which he had not read. The literary agent sent Benioff the series's first four\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Game_of_Thrones\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ebooks.[[54]] Benioff read a few hundred pages of the first novel, A Game of Thrones, shared his enthusiasm\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D._B._Weiss\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ewith D. dir=\"auto\"\u003ey y p g\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Santa_Monica_Boulevard\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e(himself a veteran screenwriter) in a restaurant on Santa Monica Boulevard. According to Benioff, they\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jon_Snow_(character)#Parentage\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ewon Martin over by knowing the answer to his question, \"Who is Jon Snow's mother?\"[[56]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eI had worked in Hollywood myself for about 10 years, from the late '80s to the '90s. I'd been on\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Twilight_Zone_(1985_TV_series)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ethe staff of The Twilight Zone and Beauty and the Beast. All of my first drafts tended to be too\u003c/a\u003e\nbig or too expensive. I always hated the process of having to cut. I said, 'I'm sick of this, I'm\ngoing to write something that's as big as I want it to be, and it's going to have a cast of\ncharacters that go into the thousands, and I'm going to have huge castles, and battles, and\ndragons.'\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e— George R. R. Martin, author[[57]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eBefore being approached by Benioff and Weiss, Martin already had meetings with other scriptwriters,\nmost of whom wanted to adapt the series as a feature film. Martin, however, deemed it \"unfilmable\",\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003esaying that the size of one of his novels is as long as The Lord of the Rings, which had been adapted as\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings_(film_series)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ethree feature films.[[57]] Benioff agreed it would be impossible to turn the novels into a feature film as their\u003c/a\u003e\nscale is too big for a feature film, and dozens of characters would have to be discarded. Benioff added, \"a\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_Picture_Association_film_rating_system\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003efantasy movie of this scope, financed by a major studio, would almost certainly need a PG-13 rating. That\u003c/a\u003e\nmeans no sex, no blood, no profanity. Fuck that.\"[[20]] Martin was pleased with the suggestion that they\nadapt it as an HBO series, saying that he \"never imagined it anywhere else\".[[58]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe series began development in January 2007.[[5]] HBO acquired the television rights to the novels, with\nBenioff and Weiss as the series' executive producers and Martin as a co-executive producer. The intention\nwas for each novel to yield a season's worth of episodes.[[5]] Initially, Martin would write one episode per\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jane_Espenson\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eseason while Benioff and Weiss would write the rest.[[5]] Jane Espenson and Bryan Cogman were added\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pilot_episode\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003elater to write one episode each for the first season.[[59]] The first and second drafts of the pilot script by\u003c/a\u003e\nBenioff and Weiss were submitted in August 2007[[60]] and June 2008,[[61]] respectively. Although HBO\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winter_Is_Coming\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eliked both drafts,[[62]] a pilot was not ordered until November 2008.[[63]] The pilot episode, \"Winter Is\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winter_Is_Coming\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eComing\", was shot in 2009; after its poor reception following a private viewing, HBO demanded an\u003c/a\u003e\nextensive re-shoot (about 90 percent of the episode, with cast and directorial changes).[[56][64]] The pilot\nreportedly cost HBO $5–10 million to produce,[[65]] while the first season's budget was estimated at $50–\n60 million.[[66]] For the second season, the series received a 15-percent budget increase for the climactic\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blackwater_(Game_of_Thrones)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ebattle in \"Blackwater\" (which had an $8 million budget).[[67][68]] Between 2012 and 2015, the average\u003c/a\u003e\nbudget per episode increased from $6 million[[69]] to \"at least\" $8 million.[[70]] The sixth-season budget was\nover $10 million per episode, for a season total of over $100 million, a record for a series's production\ncost.[[71]] By the final season, the production budget per episode was estimated to be $15 million.[[72]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv Robert Sterne were the series' primary casting directors.[[73]] Through a process of\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Dinklage\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eauditions and readings, the main cast was assembled. The only exceptions were Peter Dinklage and Sean\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sean_Bean\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eBean, whom the writers wanted from the start; they were announced as joining the pilot in 2009.[[74][75]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kit_Harington\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eOther actors signed for the pilot were Kit Harington as Jon Snow, Jack Gleeson as Joffrey Baratheon,\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Lloyd\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eHarry Lloyd as Viserys Targaryen, and Mark Addy as Robert Baratheon.[[75]] According to Benioff and\u003c/a\u003e\nWeiss, Addy was the easiest actor to cast for the series because of his audition performance.[[76]] Some\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catelyn_Stark\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003echaracters in the pilot were recast for the first season. The role of Catelyn Stark was played initially by\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e, y y g y\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emilia_Clarke\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ealso recast, with Emilia Clarke replacing Tamzin Merchant.[[78]] The rest of the first season's cast was\u003c/a\u003e\nselected in the second half of 2009.[[79]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAlthough many of the cast returned after the first season, the producers had many new characters to cast\nin each of the following seasons. Because of the large number of new characters, Benioff and Weiss\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_of_Thrones_season_2\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003epostponed introducing several key characters in the second season and merged several characters into\u003c/a\u003e\none, or assigned plot functions to different characters.[[9]] Some recurring characters were recast over the\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gregor_Clegane\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eyears; for example, Gregor Clegane was played by three different actors, while Dean-Charles Chapman\u003c/a\u003e\nplayed both Tommen Baratheon and a minor Lannister character.[[80]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eWriting\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-writing\" class=\"anchor\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Writing\" href=\"#writing\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones used seven writers over its six seasons. Benioff\u003c/em\u003e\nand Weiss wrote most of each season's episodes.[[81]] \u003cem\u003eA Song of Ice\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_R._R._Martin\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eand Fire author George R. R. Martin wrote one episode in each of\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\nthe first four seasons. Martin did not write an episode for the later\nseasons, since he wanted to focus on completing the sixth novel\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Winds_of_Winter\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e(The Winds of Winter).[[82]] Jane Espenson co-wrote one first-\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Golden_Crown\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eseason episode as a freelance writer.[[83]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eCogman, initially a script coordinator for the series,[[83]] was\npromoted to producer for the fifth season. Cogman, who wrote at\nleast one episode for the first five seasons, was the only other\nwriter in the writers' room with Benioff and Weiss.[[81]] Before\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vanessa_Taylor\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eCogman's promotion, Vanessa Taylor—a writer during the second\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dave_Hill_(screenwriter)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eand third seasons—worked closely with Benioff and Weiss. Dave\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dave_Hill_(screenwriter)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eHill joined the writing staff for the fifth season after working as an\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_R._R._Martin\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eGeorge R. R. Martin, author of A\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eassistant to Benioff and Weiss.[[84]] Although Martin was not in the\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eSong of Ice and Fire, is a series co-\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ewriters' room, he read the script outlines and made comments.[[81]] executive producer and wrote one\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eepisode for each of the first four\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eBenioff and Weiss sometimes assigned characters to particular seasons.\nwriters; for example, Cogman was assigned to Arya Stark for the\nfourth season. The writers spent several weeks writing a character\noutline, including what material from the novels to use and the overarching themes. After these individual\noutlines were completed, they spent another two to three weeks discussing each main character's\nindividual arc and arranging them episode by episode.[[81]] A detailed outline was created, with each of the\nwriters working on part of it to create a script for each episode. Cogman, who wrote two episodes for the\nfifth season, took a month and a half to complete both scripts. They were then read by Benioff and Weiss,\nwho made notes, and parts of the script were rewritten. All ten episodes were written before filming\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Film_crew\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ebegan since they were shot out of order by two units in different countries.[[81]] Benioff and Weiss wrote\u003c/a\u003e\ntheir episodes together; one wrote the first half of the script with the other writing the second half. They\nthen passed the drafts back and forth to make notes and do rewrites.[[58]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAdaptation schedule and episodes\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cem\u003ef\u003c/em\u003e y g p g p\nwas based on a plot outline of the future novels provided by Martin along with original content.[[85][86]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eBefore season four, Martin stated there was an issue with the television series being released before the\nsource material could be written.[[87]] According to Benioff, Martin gave the showrunners an outline on the\nfinal two books of the series.[[88]] In April 2016, the showrunners' plan was to shoot 13 more episodes after\nthe sixth season: seven episodes in the seventh season and six episodes in the eighth.[[89]] Later that month,\nthe series was renewed for a seventh season with a seven-episode order.[[90][91]] HBO announced in June\n2016 that the eighth season would be the final for the series.[[92]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones adaptation and season dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe first season's southern scenes were filmed in Malta, a change\nin location from the pilot episode's Moroccan sets.[[103]] The city of\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mdina\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eMdina was used for King's Landing.[[108]] Filming also took place\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Manoel\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eat Fort Manoel (representing the Sept of Baelor); at the Azure\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Azure_Window\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eWindow on the island of Gozo (the Dothraki wedding site); and at\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Anton_Palace\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eSan Anton Palace, Fort Ricasoli, Fort St. Angelo and St. Dominic\u003c/a\u003e\nmonastery (all used for scenes in the Red Keep).[[105]] Filming of\nthe second season's southern scenes shifted from Malta to Croatia,\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dubrovnik\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ewhere the city of Dubrovnik and nearby locations allowed exterior\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walls_of_Dubrovnik\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eshots of a walled, coastal medieval city. The Walls of Dubrovnik\u003c/a\u003e \u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dubrovnik\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eThe walled city of Dubrovnik stood\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Lovrijenac\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eand Fort Lovrijenac were used for scenes in King's Landing,\u003c/a\u003e in for King's Landing in season two.\nthough exteriors of some local buildings in the series, for example,\nthe Red Keep and the Sept of Baelor, are computer generated.[[109]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lokrum\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eThe island of Lokrum, the St. Dominic monastery in the coastal town of Trogir, the Rector's Palace in\u003c/a\u003e\nDubrovnik, and the Dubac quarry (a few kilometers east) were used for scenes set in Qarth. Scenes set\nnorth of the Wall, in the Frostfangs, and at the Fist of the First Men, were filmed in November 2011 in\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vatnaj%C3%B6kull\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eIceland on the Vatnajökull glacier near Smyrlabjörg, the Svínafellsjökull glacier near Skaftafell, and the\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M%C3%BDrdalsj%C3%B6kull\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eMýrdalsjökull glacier near Vik on Höfðabrekkuheiði.[[105][110]] Filming also occurred at the harbor in\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ballintoy\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eBallintoy, Northern Ireland.[[111]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThird-season production returned to Dubrovnik, with the Walls of\nDubrovnik, Fort Lovrijenac, and nearby locations again used for\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trsteno_Arboretum\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003escenes in King's Landing and the Red Keep.[[112]] Trsteno\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trsteno_Arboretum\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eArboretum, a new location, is the garden of the Tyrells in King's\u003c/a\u003e\nLanding. The third season also returned to Morocco (including the\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Essaouira\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ecity of Essaouira) to film Daenerys's scenes in Essos.[[113]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dimmuborgir\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eDimmuborgir and the Grjótagjá cave in Iceland were used as\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bart_the_Bear_2\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ewell.[[110]] One scene, with a live bear, was filmed in on\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAngeles.[[114]] The production used three units (Dragon, Wolf and\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ethe Iron Córdoba.[[117]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navarra\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eThe sixth season, which began filming in July 2015, other filming in Iceland, Northern Ireland and many locations in Spain,[[120]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C%C3%A1ceres,_Spain\" y, p\nFilming for season eight began in October 2017 and concluded in July 2018.[[123][124]] New filming\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moneyglass\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003elocations included Moneyglass and Saintfield in Northern Ireland for \"The Long Night\" battle scenes.[[125]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEffect on locations\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Screen\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eNorthern Ireland Screen, a UK government agency financed by Invest NI and the European Regional\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Regional_Development_Fund\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eDevelopment Fund, helped fund Game of Thrones.[[126]] Tourism Ireland has a Game of Thrones-themed\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tolkien_tourism\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003emarketing campaign similar to New Zealand's Tolkien-related advertising.[[127][128]] According to First\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arlene_Foster\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eMinister Arlene Foster, the series has given Northern Ireland the most publicity in its history apart from\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Troubles\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eThe Troubles.[[129]] The production of\u003c/a\u003e \u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones and other TV series boosted Northern Ireland's\u003c/em\u003e\ncreative industries, contributing to an estimated 12.4 percent growth in arts, entertainment and recreation\njobs between 2008 and 2013 (compared with 4.3 percent in the rest of the UK during the same\nperiod).[[130]] After filming had finished, HBO converted its filming locations in Northern Ireland into\ntourist attractions to be opened in 2019.[[131]] By 2019, 350,000 visitors, or one sixth of all tourists, came\nto Northern Ireland annually because of Game of Thrones.[[132]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTourism organizations elsewhere reported increases in bookings after their locations appeared in Game of\n\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hotels.com\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eThrones. Between 2014 and 2016, Hotels.com reported hotel bookings increased by 285 percent in\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ouarzazate\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eIceland and 120 percent in Dubrovnik.[[133]] In 2016, bookings doubled in Ouarzazate, Morocco, the\u003c/a\u003e\nlocation of Daenerys' season three scenes.[[134]] Dubrovnik also saw an increase in overnight tourist stays\nafter episodes aired.[[135]] However, the increase in tourism driven by the series—estimated to be\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Overtourism\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eresponsible for half of its annual increase over many years—led to concerns about \"over-tourism\" and its\u003c/a\u003e\nmayor imposing limits on tourist numbers in the city.[[119][136]] Following the series finale, HBO\nannounced in April 2019 a new exhibition and tourist attraction containing show props and set\npieces.[[137]] The attraction, titled \u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones Studio Tour, will be located at former show filming\u003c/em\u003e\nlocation Linen Mill Studios outside Belfast.[[138]] Studies showed that the series had an overall positive\neconomic impact for both Northern Ireland and Dubrovnik.[[139][140]] Despite the positive economic\nresults, some academics note the impact and damage from \u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones–related tourist activities\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Historical_site\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ecould have on historical sites and Trenton. At the beginning of the fourth\u003c/a\u003e\nseason, Engelen's team was replaced by Jane Walker and her\ncrew, composed of Ann McEwan and Barrie and Sarah Gower.[[153][154]] Over 130 makeup artists and\nprosthetic designers worked on the show.[[155][156]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japanese_armor\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eThe designs for the series's costumes were inspired by several sources, such as Japanese and Persian\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bedouin\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003earmor.[[157][158]] Dothraki dress resembles that of the Bedouin (one was made of fish skins to resemble\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inuit\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003edragon scales), and the Wildlings wear animal skins like the Inuit.[[159]] Wildling bone armor is made from\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catgut\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003emolds of actual bones and is assembled with string and latex resembling catgut.[[160]] Although the extras\u003c/a\u003e\nwho played Wildlings and the Night's Watch often wore hats (normal in a cold climate), members of the\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bj%C3%B6rk\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eprincipal cast usually did not so viewers could recognize them. Björk's Alexander McQueen high-\u003c/a\u003e\nneckline dresses inspired Margaery Tyrell's funnel-neck outfit, and prostitutes' dresses were designed for\neasy removal.[[159]] All the clothing used during the production was aged for two weeks, so it had a\nrealistic appearance on high-definition television.[[160]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAbout two dozen wigs were used by the actresses. Made of human hair and up to 61 centimetres (2 ft) in\nlength, they cost up to $7,000 each and were washed and styled like real hair. Applying the wigs was\ntime-consuming; Emilia Clarke, for example, required about two hours to style her brunette hair with a\nplatinum-blonde wig and braids. Other actors, such as Jack Gleeson and Sophie Turner, received frequent\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hair_coloring\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ehair coloring. For characters such as Daenerys (Clarke) and her Dothraki, their hair, wigs and costumes\u003c/a\u003e\nwere processed to appear as if they had not been washed for weeks.[[159]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eVisual effects\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-visual-effects\" class=\"anchor\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Visual effects\" href=\"#visual-effects\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_effects\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eFor the large number of visual effects used in the series, HBO hired British-based BlueBolt and Irish-\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2.5D\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ebased Screen Scene for season one. Most of the environment builds were done as 2.5D projections,\u003c/a\u003e\ngiving viewers perspective while keeping the programming from being overwhelming.[[161]] In 2011, the\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fire_and_Blood_(Game_of_Thrones)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eseason one finale, \"Fire and Blood\", was nominated for a Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primetime_Emmy_Award_for_Outstanding_Special_Visual_Effects\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eSpecial Visual Effects.[[153]] The visual effects crew consisted of both on-set VFX supervisors and concept\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Concept_art\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eartists along with visual effect editors in post-production.[[162]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_graphics\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eBecause the effects became more complex in subsequent seasons (including CGI creatures, fire, and\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pixomondo\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ewater), German-based Pixomondo became the lead visual effects producer; nine of its twelve facilities\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stuttgart\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003econtributed to the project for season two, with Stuttgart the lead studio.[[163][164]] Scenes were also\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ep y p\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Valar_Morghulis\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eMorghulis\" and \"Valar Dohaeris\" earned Pixomondo Primetime Emmy Awards for Outstanding Special\u003c/a\u003e\nVisual Effects in 2012 and 2013, respectively.[[153]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Children_(Game_of_Thrones)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eHBO added German-based Mackevision to the project in season four.[[165]] The season four finale, \"The\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Children_(Game_of_Thrones)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eChildren\", won the 2014 Emmy Award for Visual Effects. Additional producers for season four included\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rodeo_FX\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eCanadian-based Rodeo FX, German-based Scanline VFX and US-based BAKED FX. The muscle and\u003c/a\u003e\nwing movements of the adolescent dragons in seasons four and five were based largely on those of a\nchicken. Pixomondo retained a team of 22 to 30 people focused solely on visualizing Daenerys\nTargaryen's dragons, with the average production time per season of 20 to 22 weeks.[[166]] For the fifth\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image_Engine\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eseason, HBO added Canadian-based Image Engine and US-based Crazy Horse Effects to its list of main\u003c/a\u003e\nvisual-effects producers.[[167][168]] Visual effect supervisor Joe Bauer said that the VFX team worked on\nmore than \"10,000 shots of visual effects\" throughout all eight seasons.[[169]] More than 300 artists worked\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Creative_Arts_Emmy_Award\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eon the show's visual effects team.[[170]] The show won eight Creative Arts Emmy Awards for visual effects,\u003c/a\u003e\nwinning for Outstanding Special Visual Effects in seven consecutive seasons.[[171][172]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTitle sequence\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Title_sequence\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eThe series's title sequence was created for HBO by production studio Elastic.[[173]] Creative director Angus\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angus_Wall\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eWall and his collaborators received the 2011 Primetime Emmy Award for Main Title Design for the\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raised-relief_map\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003esequence,[[174]] which depicts a three-dimensional map of the series's fictional world. The map is projected\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Armillary_sphere\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eon the inside of a sphere which is centrally lit by a small sun in an armillary sphere.[[175]] As the camera\u003c/a\u003e\nmoves across the map, focusing on the locations of the episode's events, clockwork mechanisms\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Music_of_Game_of_Thrones\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eintertwine and allow buildings and other structures to emerge from the map. Accompanied by the title\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Music_of_Game_of_Thrones\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003emusic, the names of the principal cast and creative staff appear. The sequence concludes after about 90\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opening_credits\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eseconds with the title card and brief opening credits detailing the episode's writer(s) and director. Its\u003c/a\u003e\ncomposition changes as the story progresses, with new locations replacing those featuring less\nprominently or not at all.[[175][176]] \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eEntertainment Weekly named the title sequence one of the best on\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\ntelevision, calling it an \"all-inclusive cruise of Westeros\".[[177]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eMusic\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-music\" class=\"anchor\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Music\" href=\"#music\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramin_Djawadi\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eRamin Djawadi composed the series's music. The first season's\u003c/a\u003e\nsoundtrack, written about ten weeks before the series's premiere,[[178]] was\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Var%C3%A8se_Sarabande\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003epublished by Varèse Sarabande in June 2011.[[179]] Soundtrack albums for\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_National_(band)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003esubsequent seasons have been released, with tracks by the National, the\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Hold_Steady\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eHold Steady and Sigur Rós.[[180]] Djawadi composed reoccurring themes\u003c/a\u003e\nfor each of the major houses and some main characters.[[181]] Some themes\nevolved over time. Daenerys Targaryen's theme was simple and became\nmore complex after each season. At first, her theme was played by a single\ninstrument, a cello, and Djawadi later incorporated more instruments into\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Score_Soundtrack_for_Visual_Media\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eit.[[181]] Djawadi was nominated twice for a Grammy Award for Best Score\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Score_Soundtrack_for_Visual_Media\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eSoundtrack for Visual Media for his work on the show.[[182]] In addition to\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eg y \u003cem\u003ep\u003c/em\u003e \u003cem\u003ey\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/For_the_Throne:_Music_Inspired_by_the_HBO_Series_Game_of_Thrones\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eSeries Game of Thrones companion album on April 26, 2019.[[183]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" British-accented English, often (but not consistently)\nwith the accent of the English region corresponding to the character's Westerosi region.[[184]] The\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yorkshire_accent\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eNortherner Eddard Stark speaks in actor Sean Bean's native northern accent, and the southern lord Tywin\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Received_Pronunciation\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eLannister speaks with a southern accent, while characters from Dorne speak English with a Spanish\u003c/a\u003e\naccent.[[185][186]] Characters foreign to Westeros often have a non-British accent.[[187]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAlthough the common language of Westeros is represented as English, the producers charged linguist\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_J._Peterson\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eDavid J. Peterson with constructing Dothraki and Valyrian languages based on the few words in the\u003c/a\u003e\nnovels.[[188][189]] Before production, Peterson wrote 300 pages of Dothraki language material, including\ntranslation and word function.[[190]] Dothraki and Valyrian dialogue is often subtitled in English.[[191]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duolingo\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eLanguage-learning company Duolingo began offering courses in High Valyrian in 2017,[[192]] of which\u003c/a\u003e\n1.2 million people signed up for between 2017 and 2020.[[193]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blu-ray\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eThe ten episodes of the first season of Game of Thrones were released as a DVD and Blu-ray box set on\u003c/a\u003e\nMarch 6, 2012. The box set includes extra background and behind-the-scenes material but no deleted\nscenes, since nearly all the footage shot for the first season was used.[[204]] The box set sold over 350,000\ncopies in the week following its release, the largest first-week DVD sales ever for an HBO series. The\nseries also set an HBO-series record for digital-download sales.[[205]] A collector's-edition box set was\nreleased in November 2012, combining the DVD and Blu-ray versions of the first season with the first\nepisode of season two. A paperweight in the shape of a dragon egg is included in the set.[[206]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ey g y\n2013.[[207]] First-day sales broke HBO records, with 241,000 box sets sold and 355,000 episodes\ndownloaded.[[208]] The third season was made available for purchase as a digital download on the\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ITunes_Store\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eAustralian iTunes Store, parallel to the US premiere, and was released on DVD and Blu-ray in region 1\u003c/a\u003e\non February 18, 2014.[[209][210]] The fourth season was released on DVD and Blu-ray on February 17,\n2015,[[211]] and the fifth season on March 15, 2016.[[212]] Blu-ray and DVD versions of the sixth season\nwere released on November 15, 2016.[[213]] Beginning in 2016, HBO began issuing Steelbook Blu-ray\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dolby_TrueHD\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003esets, which include both Dolby TrueHD 7.1 and Dolby Atmos audio options.[[214]] In 2018, the first season\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/4K_resolution\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ewas released in 4K HDR on Ultra HD Blu-ray.[[215]] Blu-ray and DVD versions of the seventh season were\u003c/a\u003e\nreleased on December 12, 2017.[[216]] The final season was released on DVD and Blu-ray on December 3,\n2019. The home release also included behind-the-scenes footage and cast commentary.[[217]] A box set\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conan_O%27Brien\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003econtaining all eight seasons, including a cast reunion hosted by Conan O'Brien, was released on DVD and\u003c/a\u003e\nBlu-ray on December 3, 2019,[[218]] and was also released on 4K Ultra HD Blu-ray on November 3,\n2020.[[219]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/4K_resolution\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eIn August 2022, the complete series was released in 4K, href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Copyright_infringement_of_audio-visual_works\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eGame of Thrones has been widely pirated, primarily outside the US.[[221]] According to the file-sharing\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TorrentFreak\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003enews website TorrentFreak, it was the most pirated television series from 2012 to 2019 (except 2018,\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guinness_World_Records\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ewhen no new episodes were broadcast),[[222][223]] and Guinness World Records named it the most-pirated\u003c/a\u003e\ntelevision program in 2015.[[224]] Illegal downloads increased to about seven million in the first quarter of\n2015, up 45 percent from 2014.[[221]] An unnamed episode was downloaded about 4.28 million times\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BitTorrent_tracker\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ethrough public BitTorrent trackers in 2012, roughly equal to its number of broadcast viewers.[[225][226]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeff_Bleich\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ePiracy rates were particularly high in Australia[[227]] prompting the US Ambassador to Australia, Jeff\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeff_Bleich\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eBleich, to issue a statement in 2013 condemning the practice there.[[228]] Delays in availability by non-\u003c/a\u003e\nHBO broadcasters before 2015 and the cost of subscriptions to their services have been cited as causes\nfor the series's illegal distribution.[[229]] According to TorrentFreak, a subscription to a service\nbroadcasting Game of Thrones cost up to $25 per month in the United States, up to £26 per episode in the\nUK and up to $52 per episode in Australia.[[230]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIn 2013, to combat unauthorized downloads, HBO said it intended to make its content more widely\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HBO_Go\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eavailable within a week of the US premiere (including HBO Go).[[231]] In 2015, the fifth season was\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulcast\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003esimulcast to 170 countries and to HBO Now users.[[221]] On April 11, the day before the season premiere,\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Screener_(promotional)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003escreener copies of the first four episodes of the fifth season leaked to a number of file-sharing\u003c/a\u003e\nwebsites.[[232]] Within a day of the leak, the files were downloaded over 800,000 times;[[233]] in one week\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Wars_to_Come\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ethe illegal downloads reached 32 million, with the season five premiere—\"The Wars to Come\"— pirated\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mother%27s_Mercy\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e13 million times.[[234]] The season five finale (\"Mother's Mercy\") was the most simultaneously shared file\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BitTorrent\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ein the history of the BitTorrent file sharing protocol, with over 250,000 sharers and over 1.5 million\u003c/a\u003e\ndownloads in eight hours.[[235]] HBO did not send screeners to the press for the sixth season to prevent the\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spoiler_(media)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003espread of unlicensed copies and spoilers.[[236]] Season seven was either illegally streamed or downloaded\u003c/a\u003e\nover 1 billion times, with the season averaging 14.7 billion illegal views, and the season finale garnering\nover 120 million illegal views within its first 72 hours.[[237]] According to anti-piracy company MUSO, the\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eg g y g p\nfinal season was double the number of legal viewers, with 55 million illegal downloads for the season\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winterfell_(Game_of_Thrones_episode)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eeight premiere \"Winterfell\", compared to 17.4 million who watched on HBO platforms.[[239]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_Warner\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eObservers, including series director David Petrarca and Time Warner CEO Jeff Bewkes, said that illegal\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marketing_buzz\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003edownloads did not hurt the series's prospects; it benefited from \"buzz\" and social commentary, and the\u003c/a\u003e\nhigh piracy rate did not significantly translate into lost subscriptions.[[240][241]] According to \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polygon_(website)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ePolygon,\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\nHBO's relaxed attitude towards piracy and the sharing of login credentials amounted to a premium\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free-to-play\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003etelevision \"free-to-play\" model.[[242]] At a 2015 Oxford Union panel discussion, series co-creator David\u003c/a\u003e\nBenioff said that he was just glad that people watched the series; illegally downloaded episodes\nsometimes interested viewers enough to buy a copy, especially in countries where Game of Thrones was\nnot televised. Series co-creator D. B. Weiss had mixed feelings, saying that the series was expensive to\nproduce and \"if it doesn't make the money back, then it ceases to exist\". However, he was pleased that so\nmany people \"enjoy the show so much they can't wait to get their hands on it.\"[[243]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch2 praising the character development.[[272]] \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TV_Guide\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eTV Guide named the third season's\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Rains_of_Castamere\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003epenultimate episode \"The Rains of Castamere\" as number three on their 65 Best Episodes of the 21st\u003c/a\u003e\nCentury.[[273]] The critical acclaim continued into season four, with Darren Franich of \u003cem\u003eEntertainment\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eWeekly calling the season \" the height of the show's icon-generating powers\".[[274]]\u003c/em\u003e \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Independent\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eThe Independent stated\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\nthat the show deviated significantly from the novels however the \"changes benefited the show and\ncondensed the substantial source text admirably well\".[[275]] The critical response to season five was again\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unbowed,_Unbent,_Unbroken\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003epositive, however, some commentators criticized the sexual assault in the \"Unbowed, Unbent, Unbroken\"\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_(magazine)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eepisode.[[276]] Season six also received favorable reviews. Time criticized the repetitive story lines early in\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_the_Bastards\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ethe season, however, its reviewer praised the \"Battle of the Bastards\" episode as \"one of the show's very\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Women%27s_empowerment\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ebest\".[[277]] One reviewer also said there were \"more woman-friendly\" themes throughout the season,[[278]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ewith another singling out Arya Stark's story arc.[[279]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAs the seasons progressed, due to lack of new material from the books the show became less character\ndriven and more reliant on big twists and spectacle.[[280]] The show's final two seasons, especially season\neight, received more criticism. Season seven was praised for its action sequences and focused central\ncharacters, but received criticism for its pace and plot developments that were said to have \"defied\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vox_(website)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003elogic\".[[257][256][281]] Writing for Vox, Emily VanDerWerff cited the departure from the source material as a\u003c/a\u003e\nreason for the \"circular storytelling\".[[282]] Critical reception for season eight was mixed.[[283]] \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Guardian\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eThe\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Guardian\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eGuardian said there was the \"rushed business\" of the plot which \"failed to do justice to its characters or\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\nits actors\".[[284]] Writing for \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eThe Hollywood Reporter, Maureen Ryan condemned the season's reductive\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\ntreatment of women, and \"decisions set up and executed with little or no foresight or thoughtfulness\",\ndeclaring the penultimate episode as \"Game of Thrones at its worst\".[[285]] Fan reaction was mixed for the\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Change.org\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003efinal season. A petition on Change.org started by some fans requested that the final season be remade\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Television_Critics_Association\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ewith different writers.[[286]] Casey Bloys, HBO's president of programming, said at a Television Critics\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Television_Critics_Association\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eAssociation event \"the petition shows a lot of enthusiasm and passion for the show but it wasn't\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Guardian\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003esomething we seriously considered\".[[287]] In 2023, Game of Thrones was included on The Guardian's list\u003c/a\u003e\nof worst TV endings of all time.[[288]] Despite the criticism of the writing, the music and visual effects\nwere praised.[[289][290]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe cast performances were praised throughout the show's run. Peter Dinklage's \"charming, morally\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primetime_Emmy_Award_for_Outstanding_Supporting_Actor_in_a_Drama_Series\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eambiguous, and self-aware\"[[291]] portrayal of Tyrion, which earned him Emmy and Golden Globe awards,\u003c/a\u003e\nwas acclaimed. \"In many ways, Game of Thrones belongs to Dinklage\", wrote Mary McNamara of the\n\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eLos Angeles Times before Tyrion became the series's central figure in season two.[[292][293]] Several critics\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\nhighlighted performances by actresses and children.[[292][294]] Lena Headey's portrayal of the \"riveting\"\nCersei Lannister also received praise.[[291][295]] Maisie Williams was singled out as well and her season\ntwo work with veteran actor Charles Dance (Tywin Lannister).[[296]] Stephen Dillane received positive\nreviews for his performance as Stannis Baratheon, especially in the fifth season, with one critic noting\n\"Whether you like Stannis or not, you have to admit that Stephen Dillane delivered a monumental\nperformance this season.\"[[297]] The series was also praised for the portrayal of handicapped and disabled\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_(mythology)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003echaracters.[[298]] One commentator stated that Tyrion Lannister is a \"departure from the archetypal dwarf\"\u003c/a\u003e\noften found in other fantasy stories like The Lord of the Rings.[[299]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eDarren Franich of Entertainment Weekly gave the series a 'B' rating, saying that it was ultimately \"okay\".\nWith both \"transcendent moments\" and \"miserable phases\", it was \"beloved enough to be criticized by\neveryone for something\". Franich described seasons three and four as \"relentless\", seasons six's ending\nhaving a \"killer one-two punch\", while seasons seven and eight were \"indifferent\".[[300]] \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_New_York_Times\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eThe New York\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eg g\ntheir lack of complexity and a meandering plot.[[301]] The show, however, appeared on many \"best of\" lists\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010s#Television\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003efor the end of the 2010s. Alan Sepinwall, writing for Rolling Stone, placed the series on his \"50 Best TV\u003c/a\u003e\nShows of the 2010s\" list, saying its \"ability to most of the time keep all of its disparate threads feeling\nvital and tied to one another, remains a staggering achievement\".[[302]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eConcerns over depiction of sex and violence\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eDespite its otherwise enthusiastic reception by critics, \u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones has been criticized for the\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexual_violence\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eamount of female nudity, violence, and sexual violence it depicts, and for the manner in which it depicts\u003c/a\u003e\nthese themes.[[303][304]] George R. R. Martin responded that he felt obliged to be truthful about history and\nhuman nature, and that rape and sexual violence are common in war; and that omitting them from the\nnarrative would have rung false and undermined one of his novels' themes, its historical realism.[[305]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eHBO said that they \"fully support the vision and artistry of Dan and David's exceptional work and we feel\nthis work speaks for itself\".[[21]] The show has reportedly been censored or banned for sexual or violent\ncontent in countries like China,[[306][307]] India,[[308][309]] Iran,[[310]] Jordan,[[311]] Singapore,[[312]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTurkey,[[313][314]] United Arab Emirates,[[315]] and Vietnam.[[316]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe amount of sex and nudity in the series, especially in scenes incidental to the plot, was the focus of\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_of_Thrones_season_1\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003emuch of the criticism aimed at it in its first and second seasons. Stephen Dillane, who portrays Stannis\u003c/a\u003e\nBaratheon, likened the series's frequent explicit scenes to \"German porn from the 1970s\".[[317]] The series's\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexposition\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003euse of \"sexposition\", plot delivery accompanied by sex or nudity, was criticized as distracting.[[318]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eSaturday Night Live parodied this aspect of the adaptation in a sketch that portrayed a 13-year-old boy as\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\na Game of Thrones consultant, whose main concern was showing as many breasts as possible.[[319]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Bear_and_the_Maiden_Fair\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eThe episode \"The Bear and the Maiden Fair\" in the third season featured the lengthy torture and eventual\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emasculated\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eemasculation of Theon Greyjoy, which prompted criticism.[[320]]\u003c/a\u003e \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_(magazine)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eNew York magazine called the scene\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torture_porn\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\"torture porn\".[[321]] According to one commentator, although the series' violence tended to serve a\u003c/a\u003e\nnarrative purpose, Theon's torture in the episode was excessive as well.[[322]] One commentator noted that\nGreyjoy's emasculation was one of the few sexual assault scenes where a male was the victim.[[323]] A\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Breaker_of_Chains\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003escene in the fourth season's episode \"Breaker of Chains\", in which Jaime Lannister rapes his sister and\u003c/a\u003e\nlover Cersei in the tomb of their dead son, triggered a broad public discussion about the series' depiction\nof sexual violence against women. According to Dave Itzkoff of The New York Times, the scene caused\noutrage, in part because of comments by director Alex Graves that the scene became \"consensual by the\nend\".[[21]] \u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones has been criticized for adding scenes of rape that were not included in the\u003c/em\u003e\nnovels, such as the rape of Craster's daughters by the mutinous members of the Night's Watch.[[324]] Sonia\nSaraiya of \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_A.V._Club\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eThe A.V. Club wrote that the series's choice to portray this sexual act, and a similar one\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\nbetween Daenerys Targaryen and Khal Drogo in the first season—both described as consensual in the\nsource novels—as a rape appeared to be an act of \"exploitation for shock value\".[[325]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unbowed,_Unbent,_Unbroken\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eIn the fifth season's episode \"Unbowed, Unbent, Unbroken\", Sansa Stark is raped by Ramsay Bolton.\u003c/a\u003e\nMost reviewers and publications found the scene gratuitous and artistically unnecessary.[[326][327][328]] In\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Mary_Sue\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eresponse to the scene, pop culture website The Mary Sue announced that it would cease coverage of the\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Claire_McCaskill\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eseries because of the repeated use of rape as a plot device,[[329]] and US Senator Claire McCaskill said that\u003c/a\u003e\nshe would no longer watch it.[[330]] The episode was the lowest rated on Rotten Tomatoes until the season\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Bells_(Game_of_Thrones)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eeight episode \"The Bells\".[[331]] As the later seasons saw Daenerys, Sansa, and Cersei assume ruling\u003c/a\u003e\npositions, Alyssa Rosenberg of \u003cem\u003eThe Washington Post noted that the series could be seen as a \"long-arc\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eg y pp p g p\nMuch of the criticism after the series finale was centered around the handling of the female character\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Male_gaze\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003estorylines.[[333]] One commentator cited the male gaze as one of main sources of the \"romanticized female\u003c/a\u003e\nrape\" and general nudity throughout the series.[[323]] Another commentator stated the use of both sex and\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misogyny\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eviolence helps perpetuate misogyny within the\u003c/a\u003e \u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones universe.[[334]] Sophie Turner, who\u003c/em\u003e\nportrayed Sansa Stark, has spoken about the long-term impact she believed filming the \"heavy\" scenes\nwould have on her and revealed that she developed coping mechanisms to help her through filming.[[335]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLighting\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe lighting, or lack of light, in darker scenes has been a recurring point of criticism since season six of\nthe series.[[336][337][338][339]] In 2016, \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bustle_(magazine)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eBustle's Caitlyn Callegari listed 31 examples of scenes where the\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\nlighting caused viewers problems ranging from not being able to tell a character's hair color to being\nunable to see what was going on.[[340]] Some reviewers have noted this is part of a wider trend[[341]] among\nshows that are made by people who have experience working primarily on films, suggesting they \"haven't\ngrasped the nuances (or lack thereof)\" of television as a medium, especially the differences between\nwatching a scene on a television screen versus watching it on the big screen in a movie theater.[[342]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_McLachlan_(cinematographer)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eIn a 2017 interview, Robert McLachlan, a cinematographer working on the show, explained the lack of\u003c/a\u003e\nlighting as an artistic choice saying \"we're trying to be as naturalistic as possible\".[[343]] The criticism\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Long_Night_(Game_of_Thrones)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ereached a high point during \"The Long Night\", the third episode of season eight.[[344][345]] Barely minutes\u003c/a\u003e\ninto the episode, viewers took to social media sites such as Twitter to express their discontent over the\nfact that they were having severe difficulties watching the battle and trying to figure out what was going\non.[[346][347]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eCultural
