0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAlthough Game of Thrones was initially dismissed by some critics,[[15]] its success has been credited with\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Song_of_Ice_and_Fire#Sales\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ean increase in the fantasy genre's popularity.[[348]] The series's popularity led to increased sales of the\u003c/a\u003e \u003cem\u003eA\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Song_of_Ice_and_Fire#Sales\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eSong of Ice and Fire novels (republished in tie-in editions), which remained at the top of bestseller lists\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNN\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003efor months.[[349][350]] On the eve of the second season's premiere, CNN said, \"after this weekend, you may\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epic_fantasy\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ebe hard pressed to find someone who isn't a fan of some form of epic fantasy\" and cited Ian Bogost as\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Jackson\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003esaying that the series continues a trend of successful screen adaptations beginning with Peter Jackson's\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings_(film_series)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eThe Lord of the Rings film trilogy (2001–2003) and the\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Potter_(film_series)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eHarry Potter films (2001–2011) establishing\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gateway_drugs\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003efantasy as a mass-market genre; they are \"gateway drugs to fantasy fan culture\".[[351]] The show's success\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Wheel_of_Time_(TV_series)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eled to the commissioning of several fantasy television series, including The Wheel of Time and The Lord\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Rings_of_Power\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eof the Rings: The Rings of Power by Amazon Studios.[[352]] According to Neil Gaiman, whose novels\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Good_Omens_(TV_series)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eGood Omens and\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Gods_(TV_series)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eAmerican Gods were adapted for television,\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e \u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones helped to change\u003c/em\u003e\nattitudes towards fantasy on television, but mainly it made big budgets for fantasy series more\nacceptable.[[353]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe success of the genre has been attributed by writers to a longing for escapism in popular culture,\nfrequent female nudity and a skill in balancing lighthearted and serious topics (dragons and politics, for\nexample) which provided it with a prestige enjoyed by conventional, top-tier drama series.[[15]] According\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Daily_Beast\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eto The Daily Beast, Game of Thrones was a favorite of sitcom writers and the series has been referred to\u003c/a\u003e\nin other television series.[[354]] With other fantasy series, it has been cited as a reason for an increase in the\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huskies\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003epurchase (and abandonment) of huskies and other wolf-like dogs.[[355]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cem\u003ef\u003c/em\u003e p p y y\nexplains his motives (or background) while prostitutes have sex in the background gave rise to the word\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exposition_(literary_technique)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e\"sexposition\" for providing exposition with sex and nudity.[[356]] Dothraki, the series's nomadic horsemen,\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_Language_Monitor\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ewas ranked fourth in a September 2012 Global Language Monitor list of words from television most used\u003c/a\u003e\non the internet.[[357]] The series and its characters have also been referenced by politicians and academics\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geopolitics\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eto commentate on modern-day geopolitics, economic inequality, and climate change.[[358][359][360]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taylor_Swift\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eIn 2019, singer-songwriter Taylor Swift told Entertainment Weekly that several songs on her 2017 album\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reputation_(Taylor_Swift_album)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eReputation were inspired by Game of Thrones characters and plots.[[361]] \"Khaleesi\" became more popular\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\nas a name for baby girls in the United States. In the novels and the TV series, \"khaleesi\" is not a name,\nbut the title of the wife of a \"khal\" (warlord) in the Dothraki language, held by Daenerys Targaryen.[[362]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daenerys_(given_name)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eOther names from characters in the series, like Daenerys, also became popular baby names.[[363][364]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones has also become a subject of both academic and scientific inquiry.[[365][366]] In 2016,\u003c/em\u003e\nresearchers published a paper analyzing emotional sentiment in online public discourse associated with\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_Association_of_America\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ethe unfolding storyline during the fourth season.[[365]] The Mathematical Association of America published\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_science\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ea journal in 2016 that applied the multidisciplinary field of network science to create a social network for\u003c/a\u003e\nthe show's characters and their relationships.[[367]] The analysis purported to be able to distinguish\ndiscussions about an episode's storyline from media critiques or assessments of a specific actor's\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Survival_analysis\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eperformance. In 2018, Australian scientists conducted a survival analysis and examined the mortality\u003c/a\u003e\namong 330 important characters during the first seven seasons of \u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones.[[32]] In 2019, the\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_Red_Cross\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eAustralian Red Cross conducted a study using international humanitarian law to determine which of the\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones\u003c/em\u003e \u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_crime\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e' characters had committed the most war crimes during the first seven seasons of the\u003c/a\u003e\nshow.[[368][369]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinorhyncha\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eAnimals have also been named after the show. Three species of mud dragons; Echinoderes daenerysae,\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bombyliidae\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eEchinoderes rhaegal and Echinoderes drogoni,[[370]] a bee fly; Paramonovius nightking,[[371]] three species\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scarabaeidae\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eof scarab beetles; Gymnetis drogoni, Gymnetis rhaegali and Gymnetis viserioni,[[372]] and a brittle star,\u003c/a\u003e\nOphiohamus georgemartini, due to its sharp thorns resembling those depicted on the \u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones\u003c/em\u003e\ncrown.[[373]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones episode recap articles were a significant source of web traffic for many top news sites,\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Atlantic\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eincluding The Atlantic, The New York Times and NPR.[[374]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFandom\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fandom\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eA Song of Ice and Fire and Game of Thrones have a broad, active international fan base. In 2012 Vulture\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lady_Gaga\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eranked the series's fans as the most devoted in popular culture, more so than those of Lady Gaga, Justin\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Justin_Bieber\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eBieber, Harry Potter or Star Wars.[[375]] Fans include political leaders such as former US president Barack\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barack_Obama\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eObama,[[376][377]] former British prime minister David Cameron,[[378]] former Australian prime minister\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Julia_Gillard\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eJulia Gillard[[379]] and Dutch foreign minister Frans Timmermans, who framed European politics using\u003c/a\u003e\nquotes from Martin's novels in a 2013 speech.[[380]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BBC_News\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eBBC News said in 2013 that \"the passion and the extreme devotion of fans\" had created a phenomenon,\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fan_fiction\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eunlike anything related to other popular TV series, manifesting itself in fan fiction,[[381]]\u003c/a\u003e \u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones-\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burlesque\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ethemed burlesque routines and parents naming their children after series characters; writers quoted\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eambiguity, sexual explicitness and epic scale of the\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arya_(name)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eseries and novels.[[382]] The previous year, \"Arya\" was\u003c/a\u003e\nthe fastest-rising girl's name in the US after it had\njumped in popularity from 711th to 413th place.[[383]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAs of 2013, about 58 percent of series viewers were\nmale and 42 percent female, and the average male\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SBS_Broadcasting_Group\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eviewer was 41 years old.[[231][384]] According to SBS\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca fan-engagement rate; 5.5\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manipulated_image\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eIn this manipulated image president Barack\u003c/a\u003e online about the series in 2012, compared to 1.8 percent\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barack_Obama\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eObama (a fan of the series) rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eGame of Thrones has won numerous awards throughout its run, including 59 Emmy Awards, eight Screen\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Screen_Actors_Guild_Award\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eActors Guild Awards and a Peabody Award. It holds the record for total Emmy Award wins for a scripted\u003c/a\u003e\ntelevision series (surpassing the record of 37 wins held by \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frasier\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eFrasier since 2004) and for most Emmy\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\nnominations for a drama series, with 161.[[153][387][388][389]] In 2019, the show's final season established a\nnew record for most Emmy nominations received in a year with 32, breaking the 25-year-long record of\n26 nominations established by \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NYPD_Blue\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eNYPD Blue in 1994.[[390]] In 2013, the Writers Guild of America listed\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones as the 40th best written series in television history.[[391]] Also in 2013, at the Media\u003c/em\u003e\nAccess Awards, George R. R. Martin accepted the Visionary Award from the Writers With Disabilities\ncommittee of the Writers Guild of America, for its positive portrayal of character with disabilities.[[392]] In\n2015, \u003cem\u003eThe Hollywood Reporter placed it at number four on their best TV shows ever list,[[393]] while in\u003c/em\u003e\n2016 the series was placed seventh on \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empire_(magazine)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eEmpire's \"The 50 best TV shows ever\".[[394]] The same year,\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eRolling Stone named it the twelfth \"greatest TV Show of all time\".[[395]] In 2023, Variety ranked Game of\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eThrones No. 21 on its list of the 100 greatest TV shows of all time.[[396]]\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eViewership\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones was considered a ratings success for HBO throughout all eight seasons.[[397][398]] The\u003c/em\u003e\nshow premiere was watched by 2.2 million, and the first season averaged 2.5 million viewers per\nepisode.[[399]] For its second season, the series had an average gross audience of 11.6 million viewers.[[400]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe third season was seen by 14.2 million viewers, making \u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones the second-most-viewed\u003c/em\u003e\nHBO series (after \u003cem\u003eThe Sopranos).[[401]] HBO said that\u003c/em\u003e \u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones' average gross audience of\u003c/em\u003e\n18.4 million viewers (later adjusted to 18.6 million) had passed \u003cem\u003eThe Sopranos for the viewership\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_House_of_Black_and_White\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003erecord.[[402][403]] The season five episode \"The House of Black and White\" was simulcasted in 173\u003c/a\u003e\ncountries, becoming the \"largest TV drama telecast\" according to Guinness World Records.[[404]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ey g p p g g g\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Times\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003enearly 40 percent of viewers watching on HBO digital platforms.[[405]] In 2016, a New York Times study of\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facebook_like\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ethe 50 TV shows with the most Facebook likes found that Game of Thrones was \"much more popular in\u003c/a\u003e\ncities than in the countryside, probably the only show involving zombies that is\".[[406]] By season seven,\nthe average viewer numbers had grown to 32.8 million per episode across all platforms.[[407][408]] The\nseries finale was viewed by 19.3 million people across HBO's platforms, becoming the network's most\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hammocking\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ewatched episode.[[409][410]] The lead-out show also benefited from the finale's record viewership.[[411]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones also set viewership records outside the United States on pay-television channels in the\u003c/em\u003e\nUnited Kingdom (with a 2016 average audience of more than five million on all platforms)[[412]] and\nAustralia (with a cumulative average audience of 1.2 million).[[413]] Video streaming research company\nParrot Analytics stated that after the US, the season eight premiere demand was \"particularly strong in the\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nielsen_Media_Research\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eUnited Kingdom and France\".[[414]] Nielsen Media Research noted the show was popular among 18 to 49\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Key_demographic\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ekey demographic with strong female viewership for a fantasy series.[[415][416]] The show also benefited\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_shifting\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003efrom time shifting viewership. Between season one and season seven, 7-day viewers, the number of both\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_video_recorder\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eDVR and video on demand views during the week after the episode broadcast, grew from 3.3 million to\u003c/a\u003e\n13.7 million.[[417]] Following the show finale, commentators said many viewers might cancel their\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WarnerMedia\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003epremium television and streaming subscriptions.[[418]] HBO parent company WarnerMedia reported that\u003c/a\u003e\nsubscription revenue declined only 0.9 percent between April and June 2019.[[419]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones : U.S. rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eThronecast: The Official Guide to Game of Thrones, a series of podcasts presented by Geoff Lloyd and\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\nproduced by Koink, were released on the Sky Atlantic website and the UK iTunes store during the series's\nrun; a new podcast, with analysis and cast interviews, was released after each episode.[[429]] In 2014 and\n2015, HBO commissioned \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catch_the_Throne\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eCatch the Throne, two rap albums about the series.[[430][431]] A companion\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\nbook, Inside HBO's Game of Thrones by series writer Bryan Cogman, was published on September 27,\n2012. It aired on \u003cem\u003eHBO Now, the Monday following each season six episode.[[433]] The\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_of_Thrones_Live_Concert_Experience\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eGame of Thrones Live Concert Experience, a North American 28-city orchestral tour which performed\u003c/a\u003e\nthe series's soundtrack with composer Ramin Djawadi, began in history of Westeros.[[437]]\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFor the seventh season, this was to include the animated prequel series \u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones: Conquest \u0026amp;\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eRebellion, illustrated in a different animation style than previous videos. The series focuses on Aegon\u003c/em\u003e\nTargaryen's conquest of the Seven Kingdoms of Westeros.[[438]] A week after the series finale, HBO\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_of_Thrones:_The_Last_Watch\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ereleased a behind-the-scenes documentary entitled Game of Thrones: The Last Watch.[[439]] The program\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Read-through\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003edocumented the production of season 8 along with read-throughs and interviews with the cast.[[440]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eSuccessors\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-successors\" class=\"anchor\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Successors\" href=\"#successors\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003chr\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ey y p p\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_Borenstein\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eBorenstein, Jane Goldman, Brian Helgeland, Carly Wray, and Bryan Cogman to develop five individual\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones successor series;[[441]] the writers were to be working individually with\u003c/em\u003e\nGeorge R. R. Martin, who also co-wrote two of the scripts.[[442]] D. B. Weiss and David Benioff said that\nthey would not be involved with any of the projects.[[443]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eMartin said that all the concepts under discussion were prequels, although he believes the term \"successor\nshow\" applies better to these projects, as they are not Game of Thrones spin-offs in the traditional sense.\nHe ruled out Robert's Rebellion (the overthrow of Daenerys's father by Robert Baratheon) as a possible\nidea and revealed that some may be set outside Westeros.[[444]] In September 2018, speaking about the four\nprojects (i.e. not about Goldman's project), HBO president of programming Casey Bloys said that some\nof them had been abandoned completely, while others remained as possibilities for the future;[[445]] Martin\nsaid that: \"at least two of them are solidly based on material in Fire \u0026amp; Blood\".[[446]] In May 2019, Martin\nstated that two of the projects were still in the script stage, but were \"edging closer\".[[447]] In April 2019,\nCogman confirmed his prequel would not be moving forward.[[448]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adult_animation\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eIn January 2021, an adult animated spin-off series was announced to be in development at HBO Max.[[449]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIn July 2021, two more animated series were in development at HBO Max, with one being set in Yi Ti, a\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imperial_China\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003enation in Essos loosely based on Imperial China.[[450]] The working title is The Golden Empire.[[451]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIn March 2021, it was reported that three Game of Thrones spin-offs were in development at HBO; they\ninclude 10,000 Ships (from Amanda Segal), a reference to the voyages made by warrior queen Princess\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bruno_Heller\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eNymeria, who later founds Dorne; 9 Voyages aka The Sea Snake (from Bruno Heller), about the voyages\u003c/a\u003e\nof Corlys Velaryon on his vessel the Sea Snake; and a project based on Flea Bottom, the poorest slum in\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jon_Snow_(character)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eKing's Landing.[[452][453]] In June 2022, it was reported that a Jon Snow sequel series with Kit Harington\u003c/a\u003e\nto reprise his role was in early development at HBO.[[454]] The working title was \u003cem\u003eSnow and Martin\u003c/em\u003e\nconfirmed his involvement with the project and that Harington initiated the idea.[[453]] In April 2024,\nhowever, Harington stated the show had been shelved because they could not find a story that excited\nthem enough.[[455]] In April 2023, it was reported that a series based on Aegon Targaryen's conquest of\nWesteros was in development.[[456]] In December 2023, it was announced that \u003cem\u003eThe Sea Snake is being\u003c/em\u003e\ndeveloped as an animated series, having been previously announced as a live action series.[[457]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eBloodmoon\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eOn June 8, 2018, HBO commissioned a pilot to a \u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones prequel series from Goldman as\u003c/em\u003e\nshowrunner and Martin as co-creator.[[458]] The prequel was to take place in the Age of Heroes, a period\nthat begins roughly 10,000 years before the events of \u003cem\u003eGame of Thrones. Notable events of that period\u003c/em\u003e\ninclude the foundation of powerful Houses, the Long Night when the White Walkers first descended upon\nWesteros, and the Andal Invasion when the Andals invaded from Essos and conquered most of\nWesteros.[[459]] Martin suggested \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S._J._Clarkson\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eThe Long Night as a title for the series.[[460]] S. J. Clarkson was\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naomi_Watts\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eannounced to direct and executive produce the pilot,[[461]] while Naomi Watts was cast as the female lead\u003c/a\u003e\nplaying \"a charismatic socialite hiding a dark secret\".[[462]] Other series regulars were to include: Josh\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toby_Regbo\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eWhitehouse, Toby Regbo, Ivanno Jeremiah, Georgie Henley, Naomi Ackie, Denise Gough, Jamie\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamie_Campbell_Bower\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eCampbell Bower, Sheila Atim, Alex Sharp, Miranda Richardson, Marquis Rodriguez, John Simm,\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e,, g p, p\nwas in post-production[[464]] but in October 2019, it was announced that HBO had decided not to move\nforward with the series.[[465]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eHouse of the Dragon\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIn September 2019, \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deadline_Hollywood\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eDeadline Hollywood reported that a second prequel from Martin and Ryan Condal\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\nthat \"tracks the beginning of the end for House Targaryen\" was close to receiving a pilot order from\nHBO; the project is not considered an original sixth script, as it builds upon Cogman's idea from\n2017.[[466]] This prequel, titled House of the Dragon, was commissioned as a complete series on October\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fire_%26_Blood_(novel)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003e29, 2019. The 10-episode series is to be based on material from Fire and Blood, executive produced by\u003c/a\u003e\nMartin, Vince Gerardis, Condal, and Miguel Sapochnik; the latter two are to be its showrunners as\nwell.[[467]] In January 2020, HBO stated that the series is scheduled for a 2022 release and that the writing\nprocess has begun.[[468]] Casting for the series started in July 2020.[[469]] In October 2020, it was revealed\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paddy_Considine\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ethat Paddy Considine was cast as King Viserys I Targaryen.[[470]] In December 2020, three more castings\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olivia_Cooke\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ewere announced: Olivia Cooke as Alicent Hightower, Emma D'Arcy as Rhaenyra Targaryen, and Matt\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matt_Smith\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eSmith as Daemon Targaryen.[[471]] In February 2021, HBO chief content officer Casey Bloys stated that\u003c/a\u003e\nthe show would start production in April, with filming occurring in England.[[472][473]] In February 2021,\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Toussaint\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eSteve Toussaint, Eve Best, Rhys Ifans, and Sonoya Mizuno were confirmed to also be starring in the\u003c/a\u003e\nseries.[[474]] In March 2022, HBO announced a series premiere date of August 21, 2022, followed by the\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teaser_(trailer)\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003erelease of the official teaser trailer.[[475]]\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eA Knight of the Seven Kingdoms\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIn January 2021, it was revealed that HBO were developing another prequel series to be based on\n\u003ca href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tales_of_Dunk_and_Egg\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eMartin's novella series Tales of Dunk and Egg.[[476]] Steven Conrad was attached as writer and executive\u003c/a\u003e\nproducer of the \u003cem\u003eTales of Dunk and Egg series in November 2021.[[477]] In April 2023, HBO ordered\u003c/em\u003e <p dir="auto"><strong><em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fantasy_television" rel="nofollow">Game of Thrones is an American fantasy drama</a></em></strong>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Benioff" rel="nofollow">television series created by David Benioff and</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D._B._Weiss" rel="nofollow">D. B. Weiss for HBO. It is an adaptation of A Song of</a>
<em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Song_of_Ice_and_Fire" rel="nofollow">Ice and Fire, a series of fantasy novels by</a></em>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_R._R._Martin" rel="nofollow">George R. R. Martin, the first of which is</a> <em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Game_of_Thrones" rel="nofollow">A Game of</a></em>
<em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Game_of_Thrones" rel="nofollow">Thrones. The show premiered on HBO in the United</a></em>
States on April 17, 2011, and concluded on May 19,
2019, with 73 episodes broadcast over eight seasons.</p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westeros" rel="nofollow">Set on the fictional continents of Westeros and Essos,</a>
<em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ensemble_cast" rel="nofollow">Game of Thrones has a large ensemble cast and follows</a></em>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Story_arc" rel="nofollow">several story arcs throughout the course of the show.</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iron_Throne_(A_Song_of_Ice_and_Fire)" rel="nofollow">The first major arc concerns the Iron Throne of the</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_of_A_Song_of_Ice_and_Fire#Seven_Kingdoms" rel="nofollow">Seven Kingdoms of Westeros through a web of</a>
political conflicts among the noble families either
vying to claim the throne or fighting for independence
from whoever sits on it. The second major arc focuses
on the last descendant of the realm's deposed ruling
dynasty, who has been exiled to Essos and is plotting
to return and reclaim the throne. The third follows the
Night's Watch, a military order defending the realm
against threats from beyond the Seven Kingdoms'
northern border.</p>
<p dir="auto"><em>Game of Thrones attracted a record viewership on</em>
HBO and has a broad, active, and international fan
base. Many critics and publications have named the
show one of the greatest television series of all time.
Critics have praised the series for its acting, complex
characters, story, scope, and production values,
although its frequent use of nudity and violence
(including sexual violence) generated controversy. The
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_of_Thrones_season_8" rel="nofollow">final season received significant criticism for its</a>
reduced length and creative decisions, with many
considering it a disappointing conclusion. The series
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primetime_Emmy_Awards" rel="nofollow">received 59 Primetime Emmy Awards, the most by a</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primetime_Emmy_Award_for_Outstanding_Drama_Series" rel="nofollow">drama series, including Outstanding Drama Series in</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_awards_and_nominations_received_by_Game_of_Thrones" rel="nofollow">2015, 2016, 2018 and 2019. Its other awards and</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_awards_and_nominations_received_by_Game_of_Thrones" rel="nofollow">nominations include three Hugo Awards for Best</a></p>
<p dir="auto"><strong>Executive</strong>
<strong>producers</strong></p>

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Plot</h3><a id="user-content-plot" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Plot" href="#plot"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<p dir="auto"><em>Game of Thrones is roughly based on the storylines of</em>
the <em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Song_of_Ice_and_Fire" rel="nofollow">A Song of Ice and Fire book series by</a></em>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_R._R._Martin" rel="nofollow">George R. R. Martin, set in the fictional Seven</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_of_A_Song_of_Ice_and_Fire#Westeros" rel="nofollow">Kingdoms of Westeros and the continent of Essos.[[5][6]]</a></p>
<p dir="auto">The series follows several simultaneous plotlines.[[7]]</p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Story_arc" rel="nofollow">The first story arc follows a war of succession among</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iron_Throne_(A_Song_of_Ice_and_Fire)" rel="nofollow">competing claimants for control of the Iron Throne of</a>
the Seven Kingdoms, with other noble families
fighting for independence from the throne. The second
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lineal_descendant" rel="nofollow">concerns the actions of the exiled scion to reclaim the</a>
throne; the third chronicles the threat of the impending
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Others_(A_Song_of_Ice_and_Fire)" rel="nofollow">winter, as well as the legendary creatures and fierce</a>
peoples of the North.[[8]]</p>
<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Cast and characters</h3><a id="user-content-cast-and-characters" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Cast and characters" href="#cast-and-characters"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<p dir="auto"><em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ensemble_cast" rel="nofollow">Game of Thrones has an ensemble cast which has been</a></em>
estimated to be the largest on television.[[9]] In 2014,
several actors' contracts were renegotiated to include a
seventh-season option.[[10]] By the final season, five of
the main cast members made $1 million per episode,
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_highest_paid_American_television_stars" rel="nofollow">making them among the highest paid television</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_highest_paid_American_television_stars" rel="nofollow">performers.[[11][12]]</a></p>

<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_of_A_Song_of_Ice_and_Fire#Free_Cities_and_vicinity" rel="nofollow">Across the Narrow Sea in Pentos, siblings Viserys Targaryen (Harry Lloyd) and Daenerys Targaryen</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emilia_Clarke" rel="nofollow">(Emilia Clarke) (colloquially referred to as "Dany") are in exile, with the former plotting to reclaim his</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khal_Drogo" rel="nofollow">father's throne. Daenerys is forced into marrying Khal Drogo (Jason Momoa), a leader of the nomadic</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_of_A_Song_of_Ice_and_Fire#Dothraki_Sea" rel="nofollow">Dothraki. Her retinue eventually comes to include the exiled knight Ser Jorah Mormont (Iain Glen), her</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Missandei" rel="nofollow">aide Missandei (Nathalie Emmanuel), mercenary Daario Naharis (Michiel Huisman), and elite soldier</a>

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Themes</h3><a id="user-content-themes" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Themes" href="#themes"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<p dir="auto">Both television critics and historians have praised the series for what was perceived as a sort of medieval
realism.[[15][16][17]] George R. R. Martin set out to make the story feel more like historical fiction than
contemporary fantasy, with less emphasis on magic and sorcery and more on battles, political intrigue,
and the characters, believing that magic should be used moderately in the epic fantasy genre.[[18][19][20]]</p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orc" rel="nofollow">Martin said, "The true horrors of human history derive not from orcs and Dark Lords, but from</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neo-medievalism" rel="nofollow">ourselves".[[21]] Academics have classified the series as neo-medieval, which focuses on overlapping</a>
medieval history and popular fantasy.[[22][23][24]] A common theme in the fantasy genre is the battle
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Good_and_evil" rel="nofollow">between good and evil, which Martin says does not mirror the real world.[[25]] In the series, political</a>
leaders have mostly been portrayed negatively, as they usually disregard the well-being of the common
people and are guided in their decisions by selfish reasons. Few possible exceptions include Daenerys
Targaryen, Jon Snow and Tyrion Lannister, who have shown concern about the populace. Still, their
methods or commitment to the cause have been criticized.[[26]] Martin explores the relationship between
good and evil through the questions of redemption and character change.[[27]] Unlike in many other
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Narration#Narrative_point_of_view" rel="nofollow">fantasies, the series allows the audience to view different characters from their perspective.[[20][28]]</a></p>
<p dir="auto">In early seasons, under the influence of the A Song of Ice and Fire books, main characters were regularly
killed off, and this was credited with developing tension among viewers.[[29]] Martin stated in an interview
that he wanted to depict war and violence in a realistic way, which sometimes mean the hero or main</p>
<hr>
<p dir="auto">j, p
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plot_armor" rel="nofollow">developed "plot armor" to survive in unlikely circumstances and attributed this to</a> <em>Game of Thrones</em>
deviating from the novels to become more of a traditional television series.[[29]] In a 2012 study, out of 40
recent television drama shows, Game of Thrones ranked second in deaths per episode, averaging 14.[[31]] A
scientific study conducted in 2018 stated that about 60% of the major characters died as a result of
violence and war.[[32]]</p>
<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Inspirations and derivations</h3><a id="user-content-inspirations-and-derivations" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Inspirations and derivations" href="#inspirations-and-derivations"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<p dir="auto">Although the series's first season closely follows the events of the first novel, there were significant
changes made for later seasons. According to Benioff, the TV adaptation is "about adapting the series as a
whole and following the map George laid out for us and hitting the major milestones, but not necessarily
each of the stops along the way".[[33]] Aspects of the novels' plots and their adaptations are based upon
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/High_medieval" rel="nofollow">settings, characters, and events in European history.[[34]] Most of Westeros is reminiscent of high medieval</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feudalism" rel="nofollow">Europe, from its geography and castles to its cultures, the feudal system, palace intrigues, and the knights'</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tournament_(medieval)" rel="nofollow">tournaments.[[35][36]] Like medieval Europe, most of the houses in the series use the patriarchal system of</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gothic_fiction" rel="nofollow">power.[[37]] The series also includes elements of gothic fiction, including torture tropes.[[38]]</a></p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wars_of_the_Roses" rel="nofollow">A principal inspiration for the novels is the English Wars of the Roses (1455–1485) between the houses of</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/House_of_Lancaster" rel="nofollow">Lancaster and York, reflected in Martin's houses of Lannister and Stark.[[39]] The scheming Cersei</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isabella_of_France" rel="nofollow">Lannister evokes Isabella, the "She-Wolf of France" (1295–1358).[[34]] She and her family, as portrayed in</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maurice_Druon" rel="nofollow">Maurice Druon's historical novel series,</a> <em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Accursed_Kings" rel="nofollow">The Accursed Kings, were a main inspiration of Martin's.[[40]]</a></em></p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hadrian%27s_Wall" rel="nofollow">Other historical antecedents of series elements include: Hadrian's Wall (which becomes Martin's Wall),</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roman_Empire" rel="nofollow">the Roman Empire and the legend of Atlantis (ancient Valyria and its Doom), Damascus steel (Valyrian</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Damascus_steel#Cultural_references_and_misconceptions" rel="nofollow">Steel), Byzantine Greek fire ("wildfire"), the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World (such as the Titan of</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_of_A_Song_of_Ice_and_Fire#Braavos" rel="nofollow">Braavos and Hightower of Oldtown), Icelandic sagas of the Viking Age (the Ironborn), the Mongol</a></p>
<hr>
<p dir="auto">( ) gyp ( y)
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Italian_Renaissance" rel="nofollow">Renaissance.[[34]] The series's popularity has been attributed, in part, to Martin's skill at fusing these</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alternate_history" rel="nofollow">elements into a credible version of alternate history.[[34][41]]</a></p>

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Conception and development</h3><a id="user-content-conception-and-development" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Conception and development" href="#conception-and-development"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<p dir="auto">The A Song of Ice and Fire series of novels was popular
before <em>Game of Thrones.[[49]] The series has sold more</em>
than 90 million copies worldwide with the novels being
translated into 45 different languages.[[50][51]]</p>
<p dir="auto">George R. R. Martin received multiple fantasy writing
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Fantasy_Award" rel="nofollow">awards and nominations, including a World Fantasy</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Fantasy_Award" rel="nofollow">Award and multiple Locus Awards, for the series.[[52]]</a></p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_(magazine)" rel="nofollow">Writing for Time magazine in 2005 after the release of</a>
<em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Feast_for_Crows" rel="nofollow">A Feast for Crows, journalist Lev Grossman called</a></em>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._R._R._Tolkien" rel="nofollow">Martin the "American Tolkien", stating he is a "major</a>
force for evolution in fantasy".[[53]]</p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/D._B._Weiss" rel="nofollow">Showrunners D. B. Weiss and David Benioff</a></p>

<p dir="auto">I had worked in Hollywood myself for about 10 years, from the late '80s to the '90s. I'd been on
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Twilight_Zone_(1985_TV_series)" rel="nofollow">the staff of The Twilight Zone and Beauty and the Beast. All of my first drafts tended to be too</a>
big or too expensive. I always hated the process of having to cut. I said, 'I'm sick of this, I'm
going to write something that's as big as I want it to be, and it's going to have a cast of
characters that go into the thousands, and I'm going to have huge castles, and battles, and
dragons.'</p>
<p dir="auto">— George R. R. Martin, author[[57]]</p>
<p dir="auto">Before being approached by Benioff and Weiss, Martin already had meetings with other scriptwriters,
most of whom wanted to adapt the series as a feature film. Martin, however, deemed it "unfilmable",
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings" rel="nofollow">saying that the size of one of his novels is as long as The Lord of the Rings, which had been adapted as</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings_(film_series)" rel="nofollow">three feature films.[[57]] Benioff agreed it would be impossible to turn the novels into a feature film as their</a>
scale is too big for a feature film, and dozens of characters would have to be discarded. Benioff added, "a
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_Picture_Association_film_rating_system" rel="nofollow">fantasy movie of this scope, financed by a major studio, would almost certainly need a PG-13 rating. That</a>
means no sex, no blood, no profanity. Fuck that."[[20]] Martin was pleased with the suggestion that they
adapt it as an HBO series, saying that he "never imagined it anywhere else".[[58]]</p>
<p dir="auto">The series began development in January 2007.[[5]] HBO acquired the television rights to the novels, with
Benioff and Weiss as the series' executive producers and Martin as a co-executive producer. The intention
was for each novel to yield a season's worth of episodes.[[5]] Initially, Martin would write one episode per
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jane_Espenson" rel="nofollow">season while Benioff and Weiss would write the rest.[[5]] Jane Espenson and Bryan Cogman were added</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pilot_episode" rel="nofollow">later to write one episode each for the first season.[[59]] The first and second drafts of the pilot script by</a>
Benioff and Weiss were submitted in August 2007[[60]] and June 2008,[[61]] respectively. Although HBO
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winter_Is_Coming" rel="nofollow">liked both drafts,[[62]] a pilot was not ordered until November 2008.[[63]] The pilot episode, "Winter Is</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winter_Is_Coming" rel="nofollow">Coming", was shot in 2009; after its poor reception following a private viewing, HBO demanded an</a>
extensive re-shoot (about 90 percent of the episode, with cast and directorial changes).[[56][64]] The pilot
reportedly cost HBO $5–10 million to produce,[[65]] while the first season's budget was estimated at $50–
60 million.[[66]] For the second season, the series received a 15-percent budget increase for the climactic
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blackwater_(Game_of_Thrones)" rel="nofollow">battle in "Blackwater" (which had an $8 million budget).[[67][68]] Between 2012 and 2015, the average</a>
budget per episode increased from $6 million[[69]] to "at least" $8 million.[[70]] The sixth-season budget was
over $10 million per episode, for a season total of over $100 million, a record for a series's production
cost.[[71]] By the final season, the production budget per episode was estimated to be $15 million.[[72]]</p>

<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nina_Gold" rel="nofollow">Nina Gold and Robert Sterne were the series' primary casting directors.[[73]] Through a process of</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Dinklage" rel="nofollow">auditions and readings, the main cast was assembled. The only exceptions were Peter Dinklage and Sean</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sean_Bean" rel="nofollow">Bean, whom the writers wanted from the start; they were announced as joining the pilot in 2009.[[74][75]]</a></p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kit_Harington" rel="nofollow">Other actors signed for the pilot were Kit Harington as Jon Snow, Jack Gleeson as Joffrey Baratheon,</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Lloyd" rel="nofollow">Harry Lloyd as Viserys Targaryen, and Mark Addy as Robert Baratheon.[[75]] According to Benioff and</a>
Weiss, Addy was the easiest actor to cast for the series because of his audition performance.[[76]] Some
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catelyn_Stark" rel="nofollow">characters in the pilot were recast for the first season. The role of Catelyn Stark was played initially by</a></p>
<hr>
<p dir="auto">, y y g y
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emilia_Clarke" rel="nofollow">also recast, with Emilia Clarke replacing Tamzin Merchant.[[78]] The rest of the first season's cast was</a>
selected in the second half of 2009.[[79]]</p>
<p dir="auto">Although many of the cast returned after the first season, the producers had many new characters to cast
in each of the following seasons. Because of the large number of new characters, Benioff and Weiss
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_of_Thrones_season_2" rel="nofollow">postponed introducing several key characters in the second season and merged several characters into</a>
one, or assigned plot functions to different characters.[[9]] Some recurring characters were recast over the
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gregor_Clegane" rel="nofollow">years; for example, Gregor Clegane was played by three different actors, while Dean-Charles Chapman</a>
played both Tommen Baratheon and a minor Lannister character.[[80]]</p>
<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Writing</h3><a id="user-content-writing" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Writing" href="#writing"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<p dir="auto"><em>Game of Thrones used seven writers over its six seasons. Benioff</em>
and Weiss wrote most of each season's episodes.[[81]] <em>A Song of Ice</em>
<em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_R._R._Martin" rel="nofollow">and Fire author George R. R. Martin wrote one episode in each of</a></em>
the first four seasons. Martin did not write an episode for the later
seasons, since he wanted to focus on completing the sixth novel
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Winds_of_Winter" rel="nofollow">(The Winds of Winter).[[82]] Jane Espenson co-wrote one first-</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Golden_Crown" rel="nofollow">season episode as a freelance writer.[[83]]</a></p>
<p dir="auto">Cogman, initially a script coordinator for the series,[[83]] was
promoted to producer for the fifth season. Cogman, who wrote at
least one episode for the first five seasons, was the only other
writer in the writers' room with Benioff and Weiss.[[81]] Before
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vanessa_Taylor" rel="nofollow">Cogman's promotion, Vanessa Taylor—a writer during the second</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dave_Hill_(screenwriter)" rel="nofollow">and third seasons—worked closely with Benioff and Weiss. Dave</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dave_Hill_(screenwriter)" rel="nofollow">Hill joined the writing staff for the fifth season after working as an</a></p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_R._R._Martin" rel="nofollow">George R. R. Martin, author of A</a></p>
<p dir="auto">assistant to Benioff and Weiss.[[84]] Although Martin was not in the</p>
<p dir="auto"><em>Song of Ice and Fire, is a series co-</em></p>
<p dir="auto">writers' room, he read the script outlines and made comments.[[81]] executive producer and wrote one</p>
<p dir="auto">episode for each of the first four</p>
<p dir="auto">Benioff and Weiss sometimes assigned characters to particular seasons.
writers; for example, Cogman was assigned to Arya Stark for the
fourth season. The writers spent several weeks writing a character
outline, including what material from the novels to use and the overarching themes. After these individual
outlines were completed, they spent another two to three weeks discussing each main character's
individual arc and arranging them episode by episode.[[81]] A detailed outline was created, with each of the
writers working on part of it to create a script for each episode. Cogman, who wrote two episodes for the
fifth season, took a month and a half to complete both scripts. They were then read by Benioff and Weiss,
who made notes, and parts of the script were rewritten. All ten episodes were written before filming
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Film_crew" rel="nofollow">began since they were shot out of order by two units in different countries.[[81]] Benioff and Weiss wrote</a>
their episodes together; one wrote the first half of the script with the other writing the second half. They
then passed the drafts back and forth to make notes and do rewrites.[[58]]</p>

was based on a plot outline of the future novels provided by Martin along with original content.[[85][86]]</p>
<p dir="auto">Before season four, Martin stated there was an issue with the television series being released before the
source material could be written.[[87]] According to Benioff, Martin gave the showrunners an outline on the
final two books of the series.[[88]] In April 2016, the showrunners' plan was to shoot 13 more episodes after
the sixth season: seven episodes in the seventh season and six episodes in the eighth.[[89]] Later that month,
the series was renewed for a seventh season with a seven-episode order.[[90][91]] HBO announced in June
2016 that the eighth season would be the final for the series.[[92]]</p>

<p dir="auto">The first two seasons adapted one novel each. For the later seasons, its creators saw Game of Thrones as
an adaptation of A Song of Ice and Fire as a whole rather than the individual novels,[[101]] enabling them to
move events across novels as the screen adaptation required.[[102]]</p>

the second season's southern scenes shifted from Malta to Croatia,
