<p dir="auto">Raven) filming in parallel, six directing teams, 257 cast members
and 703 crew members.[[115]] The fourth season returned to
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diocletian%27s_Palace" rel="nofollow">Dubrovnik and included new locations, including Diocletian's Palace in Split, Klis Fortress north of Split,</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mosor" rel="nofollow">Perun quarry east of Split, the Mosor mountain range and Baška Voda farther south.[[116]] Thingvellir</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thingvellir_National_Park" rel="nofollow">National Park in Iceland was used for the fight between Brienne and the Hound.[[110]] The fifth season</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seville" rel="nofollow">added Seville, Spain, used for scenes of Dorne, and Córdoba.[[117]]</a></p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navarra" rel="nofollow">The sixth season, which began filming in July 2015, returned to Spain and filmed in Navarra,</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Province_of_Guadalajara" rel="nofollow">Guadalajara, Seville, Almeria, Girona and Peniscola.[[118]] Filming also returned to Dubrovnik,</a>
Croatia.[[119]] The filming of the seven episodes of season seven began on August 31, 2016, at Titanic
Studios in Belfast, with other filming in Iceland, Northern Ireland and many locations in Spain,[[120]]</p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C%C3%A1ceres,_Spain" rel="nofollow">including Seville, Cáceres, Almodovar del Rio, Santiponce, Zumaia and Bermeo.[[121]] Filming continued</a></p>
<hr>
<p dir="auto">y, y, p
Filming for season eight began in October 2017 and concluded in July 2018.[[123][124]] New filming
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moneyglass" rel="nofollow">locations included Moneyglass and Saintfield in Northern Ireland for "The Long Night" battle scenes.[[125]]</a></p>
<p dir="auto"><strong>Effect on locations</strong></p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Screen" rel="nofollow">Northern Ireland Screen, a UK government agency financed by Invest NI and the European Regional</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Regional_Development_Fund" rel="nofollow">Development Fund, helped fund Game of Thrones.[[126]] Tourism Ireland has a Game of Thrones-themed</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tolkien_tourism" rel="nofollow">marketing campaign similar to New Zealand's Tolkien-related advertising.[[127][128]] According to First</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arlene_Foster" rel="nofollow">Minister Arlene Foster, the series has given Northern Ireland the most publicity in its history apart from</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Troubles" rel="nofollow">The Troubles.[[129]] The production of</a> <em>Game of Thrones and other TV series boosted Northern Ireland's</em>
creative industries, contributing to an estimated 12.4 percent growth in arts, entertainment and recreation
jobs between 2008 and 2013 (compared with 4.3 percent in the rest of the UK during the same
period).[[130]] After filming had finished, HBO converted its filming locations in Northern Ireland into
tourist attractions to be opened in 2019.[[131]] By 2019, 350,000 visitors, or one sixth of all tourists, came
to Northern Ireland annually because of Game of Thrones.[[132]]</p>
<p dir="auto">Tourism organizations elsewhere reported increases in bookings after their locations appeared in Game of
<em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hotels.com" rel="nofollow">Thrones. Between 2014 and 2016, Hotels.com reported hotel bookings increased by 285 percent in</a></em>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ouarzazate" rel="nofollow">Iceland and 120 percent in Dubrovnik.[[133]] In 2016, bookings doubled in Ouarzazate, Morocco, the</a>
location of Daenerys' season three scenes.[[134]] Dubrovnik also saw an increase in overnight tourist stays
after episodes aired.[[135]] However, the increase in tourism driven by the series—estimated to be
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Overtourism" rel="nofollow">responsible for half of its annual increase over many years—led to concerns about "over-tourism" and its</a>
mayor imposing limits on tourist numbers in the city.[[119][136]] Following the series finale, HBO
announced in April 2019 a new exhibition and tourist attraction containing show props and set
pieces.[[137]] The attraction, titled <em>Game of Thrones Studio Tour, will be located at former show filming</em>
location Linen Mill Studios outside Belfast.[[138]] Studies showed that the series had an overall positive
economic impact for both Northern Ireland and Dubrovnik.[[139][140]] Despite the positive economic
results, some academics note the impact and damage from <em>Game of Thrones–related tourist activities</em>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Historical_site" rel="nofollow">could have on historical sites and other locations of cultural value.[[141]]</a></p>
<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Directing</h3><a id="user-content-directing" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Directing" href="#directing"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<p dir="auto">Each ten-episode season of Game of Thrones had four to six directors, who usually directed back-to-back
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alan_Taylor_(director)" rel="nofollow">episodes.[[142]] Alan Taylor directed seven episodes, the most of any director.[[143]] Alex Graves, David</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Nutter" rel="nofollow">Nutter, Mark Mylod, and Jeremy Podeswa directed six episodes each.[[144]] Daniel Minahan directed five</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michelle_MacLaren" rel="nofollow">episodes, and Michelle MacLaren, Alik Sakharov, and Miguel Sapochnik directed four each; MacLaren is</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brian_Kirk" rel="nofollow">the only female director of the entire series's run.[[145]] Brian Kirk directed three episodes during the first</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tim_Van_Patten" rel="nofollow">season, and Tim Van Patten directed the series's first two episodes.[[146]] Neil Marshall directed two</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Watchers_on_the_Wall" rel="nofollow">episodes, both with large battle scenes: "Blackwater" and "The Watchers on the Wall".[[147]] Other</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jack_Bender" rel="nofollow">directors include Jack Bender, David Petrarca, Daniel Sackheim, Michael Slovis and Matt Shakman.[[148]]</a></p>
<p dir="auto">David Benioff and D. B. Weiss have directed two episodes together but were credited with only one each,</p>
<hr>
<p dir="auto">g, g p,
worked on previous episodes, directed the first five episodes.[[149]] Benioff and Weiss were credited as
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Iron_Throne_(Game_of_Thrones)" rel="nofollow">both the writers and directors of the show finale "The Iron Throne".[[150]]</a></p>
<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Production design</h3><a id="user-content-production-design" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Production design" href="#production-design"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michele_Clapton" rel="nofollow">Michele Clapton was the costume designer for</a> <em>Game of</em> <strong>External videos</strong>
<em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/April_Ferry" rel="nofollow">Thrones' first five seasons before she was replaced by April</a></em></p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F_iFAjvYFo4" rel="nofollow">HBO promotional video detailing</a></p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/April_Ferry" rel="nofollow">Ferry.[[151]] Clapton returned to the series as its costume</a></p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F_iFAjvYFo4" rel="nofollow">the research and design of the</a></p>
<p dir="auto">designer for the seventh season.[[152]] For the first three seasons,</p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F_iFAjvYFo4" rel="nofollow">show's costumes (https://www.youtub</a></p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Engelen" rel="nofollow">Paul Engelen was</a> <em>Game of Thrones</em> ' main makeup designer</p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F_iFAjvYFo4" rel="nofollow">e.com/watch?v=F_iFAjvYFo4),</a></p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prosthetic_makeup" rel="nofollow">and prosthetic makeup artist with Melissa Lackersteen, Conor</a></p>
<p dir="auto">YouTube video</p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conor_O%27Sullivan_(make-up_artist)" rel="nofollow">O'Sullivan, and Rob Trenton. At the beginning of the fourth</a>
season, Engelen's team was replaced by Jane Walker and her
crew, composed of Ann McEwan and Barrie and Sarah Gower.[[153][154]] Over 130 makeup artists and
prosthetic designers worked on the show.[[155][156]]</p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japanese_armor" rel="nofollow">The designs for the series's costumes were inspired by several sources, such as Japanese and Persian</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bedouin" rel="nofollow">armor.[[157][158]] Dothraki dress resembles that of the Bedouin (one was made of fish skins to resemble</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inuit" rel="nofollow">dragon scales), and the Wildlings wear animal skins like the Inuit.[[159]] Wildling bone armor is made from</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catgut" rel="nofollow">molds of actual bones and is assembled with string and latex resembling catgut.[[160]] Although the extras</a>
who played Wildlings and the Night's Watch often wore hats (normal in a cold climate), members of the
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bj%C3%B6rk" rel="nofollow">principal cast usually did not so viewers could recognize them. Björk's Alexander McQueen high-</a>
neckline dresses inspired Margaery Tyrell's funnel-neck outfit, and prostitutes' dresses were designed for
easy removal.[[159]] All the clothing used during the production was aged for two weeks, so it had a
realistic appearance on high-definition television.[[160]]</p>
<p dir="auto">About two dozen wigs were used by the actresses. Made of human hair and up to 61 centimetres (2 ft) in
length, they cost up to $7,000 each and were washed and styled like real hair. Applying the wigs was
time-consuming; Emilia Clarke, for example, required about two hours to style her brunette hair with a
platinum-blonde wig and braids. Other actors, such as Jack Gleeson and Sophie Turner, received frequent
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hair_coloring" rel="nofollow">hair coloring. For characters such as Daenerys (Clarke) and her Dothraki, their hair, wigs and costumes</a>
were processed to appear as if they had not been washed for weeks.[[159]]</p>
<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Visual effects</h3><a id="user-content-visual-effects" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Visual effects" href="#visual-effects"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_effects" rel="nofollow">For the large number of visual effects used in the series, HBO hired British-based BlueBolt and Irish-</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2.5D" rel="nofollow">based Screen Scene for season one. Most of the environment builds were done as 2.5D projections,</a>
giving viewers perspective while keeping the programming from being overwhelming.[[161]] In 2011, the
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fire_and_Blood_(Game_of_Thrones)" rel="nofollow">season one finale, "Fire and Blood", was nominated for a Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primetime_Emmy_Award_for_Outstanding_Special_Visual_Effects" rel="nofollow">Special Visual Effects.[[153]] The visual effects crew consisted of both on-set VFX supervisors and concept</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Concept_art" rel="nofollow">artists along with visual effect editors in post-production.[[162]]</a></p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer_graphics" rel="nofollow">Because the effects became more complex in subsequent seasons (including CGI creatures, fire, and</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pixomondo" rel="nofollow">water), German-based Pixomondo became the lead visual effects producer; nine of its twelve facilities</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stuttgart" rel="nofollow">contributed to the project for season two, with Stuttgart the lead studio.[[163][164]] Scenes were also</a></p>
<hr>
<p dir="auto">p y p
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Valar_Morghulis" rel="nofollow">Morghulis" and "Valar Dohaeris" earned Pixomondo Primetime Emmy Awards for Outstanding Special</a>
Visual Effects in 2012 and 2013, respectively.[[153]]</p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Children_(Game_of_Thrones)" rel="nofollow">HBO added German-based Mackevision to the project in season four.[[165]] The season four finale, "The</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Children_(Game_of_Thrones)" rel="nofollow">Children", won the 2014 Emmy Award for Visual Effects. Additional producers for season four included</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rodeo_FX" rel="nofollow">Canadian-based Rodeo FX, German-based Scanline VFX and US-based BAKED FX. The muscle and</a>
wing movements of the adolescent dragons in seasons four and five were based largely on those of a
chicken. Pixomondo retained a team of 22 to 30 people focused solely on visualizing Daenerys
Targaryen's dragons, with the average production time per season of 20 to 22 weeks.[[166]] For the fifth
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Image_Engine" rel="nofollow">season, HBO added Canadian-based Image Engine and US-based Crazy Horse Effects to its list of main</a>
visual-effects producers.[[167][168]] Visual effect supervisor Joe Bauer said that the VFX team worked on
more than "10,000 shots of visual effects" throughout all eight seasons.[[169]] More than 300 artists worked
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Creative_Arts_Emmy_Award" rel="nofollow">on the show's visual effects team.[[170]] The show won eight Creative Arts Emmy Awards for visual effects,</a>
winning for Outstanding Special Visual Effects in seven consecutive seasons.[[171][172]]</p>
<p dir="auto"><strong>Title sequence</strong></p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Title_sequence" rel="nofollow">The series's title sequence was created for HBO by production studio Elastic.[[173]] Creative director Angus</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angus_Wall" rel="nofollow">Wall and his collaborators received the 2011 Primetime Emmy Award for Main Title Design for the</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Raised-relief_map" rel="nofollow">sequence,[[174]] which depicts a three-dimensional map of the series's fictional world. The map is projected</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Armillary_sphere" rel="nofollow">on the inside of a sphere which is centrally lit by a small sun in an armillary sphere.[[175]] As the camera</a>
moves across the map, focusing on the locations of the episode's events, clockwork mechanisms
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Music_of_Game_of_Thrones" rel="nofollow">intertwine and allow buildings and other structures to emerge from the map. Accompanied by the title</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Music_of_Game_of_Thrones" rel="nofollow">music, the names of the principal cast and creative staff appear. The sequence concludes after about 90</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Opening_credits" rel="nofollow">seconds with the title card and brief opening credits detailing the episode's writer(s) and director. Its</a>
composition changes as the story progresses, with new locations replacing those featuring less
prominently or not at all.[[175][176]] <em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly" rel="nofollow">Entertainment Weekly named the title sequence one of the best on</a></em>
television, calling it an "all-inclusive cruise of Westeros".[[177]]</p>
<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Music</h3><a id="user-content-music" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Music" href="#music"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ramin_Djawadi" rel="nofollow">Ramin Djawadi composed the series's music. The first season's</a>
soundtrack, written about ten weeks before the series's premiere,[[178]] was
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Var%C3%A8se_Sarabande" rel="nofollow">published by Varèse Sarabande in June 2011.[[179]] Soundtrack albums for</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_National_(band)" rel="nofollow">subsequent seasons have been released, with tracks by the National, the</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Hold_Steady" rel="nofollow">Hold Steady and Sigur Rós.[[180]] Djawadi composed reoccurring themes</a>
for each of the major houses and some main characters.[[181]] Some themes
evolved over time. Daenerys Targaryen's theme was simple and became
more complex after each season. At first, her theme was played by a single
instrument, a cello, and Djawadi later incorporated more instruments into
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Score_Soundtrack_for_Visual_Media" rel="nofollow">it.[[181]] Djawadi was nominated twice for a Grammy Award for Best Score</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grammy_Award_for_Best_Score_Soundtrack_for_Visual_Media" rel="nofollow">Soundtrack for Visual Media for his work on the show.[[182]] In addition to</a></p>
<hr>
<p dir="auto">g y <em>p</em> <em>y</em>
<em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/For_the_Throne:_Music_Inspired_by_the_HBO_Series_Game_of_Thrones" rel="nofollow">Series Game of Thrones companion album on April 26, 2019.[[183]]</a></em></p>
<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Language</h3><a id="user-content-language" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Language" href="#language"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<p dir="auto">The Westerosi characters of Game of Thrones speak British-accented English, often (but not consistently)
with the accent of the English region corresponding to the character's Westerosi region.[[184]] The
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yorkshire_accent" rel="nofollow">Northerner Eddard Stark speaks in actor Sean Bean's native northern accent, and the southern lord Tywin</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Received_Pronunciation" rel="nofollow">Lannister speaks with a southern accent, while characters from Dorne speak English with a Spanish</a>
accent.[[185][186]] Characters foreign to Westeros often have a non-British accent.[[187]]</p>
<p dir="auto">Although the common language of Westeros is represented as English, the producers charged linguist
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_J._Peterson" rel="nofollow">David J. Peterson with constructing Dothraki and Valyrian languages based on the few words in the</a>
novels.[[188][189]] Before production, Peterson wrote 300 pages of Dothraki language material, including
translation and word function.[[190]] Dothraki and Valyrian dialogue is often subtitled in English.[[191]]</p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Duolingo" rel="nofollow">Language-learning company Duolingo began offering courses in High Valyrian in 2017,[[192]] of which</a>
1.2 million people signed up for between 2017 and 2020.[[193]]</p>

<p dir="auto"><em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HBO" rel="nofollow">Game of Thrones was broadcast by HBO in the United States and by its local subsidiaries or other pay</a></em>

<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Showcase" rel="nofollow">Broadcasters carrying Game of Thrones included Fox Showcase in Australia; HBO Canada, Super Écran,</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Showcase_(Canadian_TV_channel)" rel="nofollow">and Showcase in Canada; HBO Latin America in Latin America; Sky Television Network's SoHo and</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neon_(service)" rel="nofollow">Neon in New Zealand; and Sky Atlantic in the United Kingdom and Ireland.[[194][195][196][197]] In India,</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_World_(Indian_TV_channel)" rel="nofollow">two versions of the series were aired; Star World aired a censored version of the series on television at the</a>

app.[[198]]</p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_of_Thrones_season_4" rel="nofollow">On January 23, 2015, the last two episodes of season four were shown in 205 IMAX theaters across the</a>
United States, the first television series to be shown in this format.[[199]] The show earned $686,000 at the
box office on its opening day[[200]] and $1.5 million during its opening weekend;[[201]] the week-long
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Spoils_of_War_(Game_of_Thrones)" rel="nofollow">release grossed $1,896,092.[[202]] Before the season eight premiere, HBO screened "The Spoils of War"</a>
episode from season seven in movie theaters in New York, Los Angeles, and Chicago.[[203]]</p>

<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blu-ray" rel="nofollow">The ten episodes of the first season of Game of Thrones were released as a DVD and Blu-ray box set on</a>
March 6, 2012. The box set includes extra background and behind-the-scenes material but no deleted
scenes, since nearly all the footage shot for the first season was used.[[204]] The box set sold over 350,000
copies in the week following its release, the largest first-week DVD sales ever for an HBO series. The
series also set an HBO-series record for digital-download sales.[[205]] A collector's-edition box set was
released in November 2012, combining the DVD and Blu-ray versions of the first season with the first
episode of season two. A paperweight in the shape of a dragon egg is included in the set.[[206]]</p>
<hr>
<p dir="auto">y g y
2013.[[207]] First-day sales broke HBO records, with 241,000 box sets sold and 355,000 episodes
downloaded.[[208]] The third season was made available for purchase as a digital download on the
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ITunes_Store" rel="nofollow">Australian iTunes Store, parallel to the US premiere, and was released on DVD and Blu-ray in region 1</a>
on February 18, 2014.[[209][210]] The fourth season was released on DVD and Blu-ray on February 17,
2015,[[211]] and the fifth season on March 15, 2016.[[212]] Blu-ray and DVD versions of the sixth season
were released on November 15, 2016.[[213]] Beginning in 2016, HBO began issuing Steelbook Blu-ray
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dolby_TrueHD" rel="nofollow">sets, which include both Dolby TrueHD 7.1 and Dolby Atmos audio options.[[214]] In 2018, the first season</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/4K_resolution" rel="nofollow">was released in 4K HDR on Ultra HD Blu-ray.[[215]] Blu-ray and DVD versions of the seventh season were</a>
released on December 12, 2017.[[216]] The final season was released on DVD and Blu-ray on December 3,
2019. The home release also included behind-the-scenes footage and cast commentary.[[217]] A box set
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conan_O%27Brien" rel="nofollow">containing all eight seasons, including a cast reunion hosted by Conan O'Brien, was released on DVD and</a>
Blu-ray on December 3, 2019,[[218]] and was also released on 4K Ultra HD Blu-ray on November 3,
2020.[[219]]</p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/4K_resolution" rel="nofollow">In August 2022, the complete series was released in 4K, Dolby Vision HDR and Dolby Atmos on HBO</a>

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Copyright infringement</h3><a id="user-content-copyright-infringement" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Copyright infringement" href="#copyright-infringement"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<p dir="auto"><em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Copyright_infringement_of_audio-visual_works" rel="nofollow">Game of Thrones has been widely pirated, primarily outside the US.[[221]] According to the file-sharing</a></em>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TorrentFreak" rel="nofollow">news website TorrentFreak, it was the most pirated television series from 2012 to 2019 (except 2018,</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guinness_World_Records" rel="nofollow">when no new episodes were broadcast),[[222][223]] and Guinness World Records named it the most-pirated</a>
television program in 2015.[[224]] Illegal downloads increased to about seven million in the first quarter of
2015, up 45 percent from 2014.[[221]] An unnamed episode was downloaded about 4.28 million times
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BitTorrent_tracker" rel="nofollow">through public BitTorrent trackers in 2012, roughly equal to its number of broadcast viewers.[[225][226]]</a></p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeff_Bleich" rel="nofollow">Piracy rates were particularly high in Australia[[227]] prompting the US Ambassador to Australia, Jeff</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeff_Bleich" rel="nofollow">Bleich, to issue a statement in 2013 condemning the practice there.[[228]] Delays in availability by non-</a>
HBO broadcasters before 2015 and the cost of subscriptions to their services have been cited as causes
for the series's illegal distribution.[[229]] According to TorrentFreak, a subscription to a service
broadcasting Game of Thrones cost up to $25 per month in the United States, up to £26 per episode in the
UK and up to $52 per episode in Australia.[[230]]</p>
<p dir="auto">In 2013, to combat unauthorized downloads, HBO said it intended to make its content more widely
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HBO_Go" rel="nofollow">available within a week of the US premiere (including HBO Go).[[231]] In 2015, the fifth season was</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulcast" rel="nofollow">simulcast to 170 countries and to HBO Now users.[[221]] On April 11, the day before the season premiere,</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Screener_(promotional)" rel="nofollow">screener copies of the first four episodes of the fifth season leaked to a number of file-sharing</a>
websites.[[232]] Within a day of the leak, the files were downloaded over 800,000 times;[[233]] in one week
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Wars_to_Come" rel="nofollow">the illegal downloads reached 32 million, with the season five premiere—"The Wars to Come"— pirated</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mother%27s_Mercy" rel="nofollow">13 million times.[[234]] The season five finale ("Mother's Mercy") was the most simultaneously shared file</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BitTorrent" rel="nofollow">in the history of the BitTorrent file sharing protocol, with over 250,000 sharers and over 1.5 million</a>
downloads in eight hours.[[235]] HBO did not send screeners to the press for the sixth season to prevent the
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spoiler_(media)" rel="nofollow">spread of unlicensed copies and spoilers.[[236]] Season seven was either illegally streamed or downloaded</a>
over 1 billion times, with the season averaging 14.7 billion illegal views, and the season finale garnering
over 120 million illegal views within its first 72 hours.[[237]] According to anti-piracy company MUSO, the</p>
<hr>
<p dir="auto">g g y g p
final season was double the number of legal viewers, with 55 million illegal downloads for the season
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winterfell_(Game_of_Thrones_episode)" rel="nofollow">eight premiere "Winterfell", compared to 17.4 million who watched on HBO platforms.[[239]]</a></p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_Warner" rel="nofollow">Observers, including series director David Petrarca and Time Warner CEO Jeff Bewkes, said that illegal</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marketing_buzz" rel="nofollow">downloads did not hurt the series's prospects; it benefited from "buzz" and social commentary, and the</a>
high piracy rate did not significantly translate into lost subscriptions.[[240][241]] According to <em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polygon_(website)" rel="nofollow">Polygon,</a></em>
HBO's relaxed attitude towards piracy and the sharing of login credentials amounted to a premium<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free-to-play" rel="nofollow">television "free-to-play" model.[[242]] At a 2015 Oxford Union panel discussion, series co-creator David</a>
Benioff said that he was just glad that people watched the series; illegally downloaded episodes
sometimes interested viewers enough to buy a copy, especially in countries where Game of Thrones was
not televised. Series co-creator D. B. Weiss had mixed feelings, saying that the series was expensive to
produce and "if it doesn't make the money back, then it ceases to exist". However, he was pleased that so
many people "enjoy the show so much they can't wait to get their hands on it."[[243]]</p>

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Critical response</h3><a id="user-content-critical-response" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Critical response" href="#critical-response"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<p dir="auto"><strong>General</strong></p>
<p dir="auto"><em>Game of Thrones, particularly the first six</em>
seasons, received critical acclaim, although the <strong>Season</strong> <strong><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes" rel="nofollow">Rotten Tomatoes</a></strong> <strong><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metacritic" rel="nofollow">Metacritic</a></strong>
series's frequent use of nudity and violence has <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_of_Thrones_season_1#Critical_response" rel="nofollow">1</a> 90% (224 reviews)[[244]] 80 (28 reviews)[[245]]
been criticized. The series has an overall rating</p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_of_Thrones_season_2#Critical_response" rel="nofollow">2</a> 96% (304 reviews)[[246]] 90 (26 reviews)[[247]]</p>
<p dir="auto">of 89% on Rotten Tomatoes and a score of 86 on</p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_of_Thrones_season_3#Critical_response" rel="nofollow">3</a> 96% (419 reviews)[[248]] 91 (25 reviews)[[249]]</p>
<p dir="auto">Metacritic.[[260][261]] Some critics and
publications have called the show among the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_of_Thrones_season_4#Critical_response" rel="nofollow">4</a> 97% (571 reviews)[[250]] 94 (29 reviews)[[251]]
best HBO series of all time.[[262][263]] The series <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_of_Thrones_season_5#Critical_response" rel="nofollow">5</a> 93% (574 reviews)[[252]] 91 (29 reviews)[[253]]
was highly anticipated by fans before its</p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_of_Thrones_season_6#Critical_response" rel="nofollow">6</a> 94% (667 reviews)[[254]] 73 (9 reviews)[[255]]</p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Poniewozik" rel="nofollow">premiere.[[264][265]] James Poniewozik said the</a></p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_of_Thrones_season_7#Critical_response" rel="nofollow">7</a> 93% (418 reviews)[[256]] 77 (12 reviews)[[257]]</p>
<p dir="auto">pilot episode set "a very large table",[[266]] while</p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_of_Thrones_season_8#Critical_response" rel="nofollow">8</a> 55% (699 reviews)[[258]] 75 (13 reviews)[[259]]</p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Den_of_Geek" rel="nofollow">Ti Singh of Den of Geek said the show "is here</a>
to stay".[[267]]</p>
<p dir="auto">First-season reviewers said the series had high production values, a fully realized world and compelling
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Variety_(magazine)" rel="nofollow">characters.[[268]] According to Variety, "There may be no show more profitable to its network than 'Game</a>
of Thrones' is to HBO. Fully produced by the pay cabler and already a global phenomenon after only one
season, the fantasy skein was a gamble that has paid off handsomely."[[269]] The second season was also
well received. <em>Entertainment Weekly praised its "vivid, vital, and just plain fun" storytelling[[270]] and,</em>
according to The Hollywood Reporter, the series made a "strong case for being one of TV's best series";
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mad_Men" rel="nofollow">its seriousness made it the only drama comparable to Mad Men or Breaking Bad.[[271]]</a></p>

<p dir="auto">p p
"still quite marvelous" praising the character development.[[272]] <em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TV_Guide" rel="nofollow">TV Guide named the third season's</a></em>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Rains_of_Castamere" rel="nofollow">penultimate episode "The Rains of Castamere" as number three on their 65 Best Episodes of the 21st</a>
Century.[[273]] The critical acclaim continued into season four, with Darren Franich of <em>Entertainment</em>
<em>Weekly calling the season " the height of the show's icon-generating powers".[[274]]</em> <em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Independent" rel="nofollow">The Independent stated</a></em>
that the show deviated significantly from the novels however the "changes benefited the show and
condensed the substantial source text admirably well".[[275]] The critical response to season five was again
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unbowed,_Unbent,_Unbroken" rel="nofollow">positive, however, some commentators criticized the sexual assault in the "Unbowed, Unbent, Unbroken"</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_(magazine)" rel="nofollow">episode.[[276]] Season six also received favorable reviews. Time criticized the repetitive story lines early in</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_the_Bastards" rel="nofollow">the season, however, its reviewer praised the "Battle of the Bastards" episode as "one of the show's very</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Women%27s_empowerment" rel="nofollow">best".[[277]] One reviewer also said there were "more woman-friendly" themes throughout the season,[[278]]</a></p>
<p dir="auto">with another singling out Arya Stark's story arc.[[279]]</p>
<p dir="auto">As the seasons progressed, due to lack of new material from the books the show became less character
driven and more reliant on big twists and spectacle.[[280]] The show's final two seasons, especially season
eight, received more criticism. Season seven was praised for its action sequences and focused central
characters, but received criticism for its pace and plot developments that were said to have "defied
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vox_(website)" rel="nofollow">logic".[[257][256][281]] Writing for Vox, Emily VanDerWerff cited the departure from the source material as a</a>
reason for the "circular storytelling".[[282]] Critical reception for season eight was mixed.[[283]] <em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Guardian" rel="nofollow">The</a></em>
<em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Guardian" rel="nofollow">Guardian said there was the "rushed business" of the plot which "failed to do justice to its characters or</a></em>
its actors".[[284]] Writing for <em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter" rel="nofollow">The Hollywood Reporter, Maureen Ryan condemned the season's reductive</a></em>
treatment of women, and "decisions set up and executed with little or no foresight or thoughtfulness",
declaring the penultimate episode as "Game of Thrones at its worst".[[285]] Fan reaction was mixed for the
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Change.org" rel="nofollow">final season. A petition on Change.org started by some fans requested that the final season be remade</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Television_Critics_Association" rel="nofollow">with different writers.[[286]] Casey Bloys, HBO's president of programming, said at a Television Critics</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Television_Critics_Association" rel="nofollow">Association event "the petition shows a lot of enthusiasm and passion for the show but it wasn't</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Guardian" rel="nofollow">something we seriously considered".[[287]] In 2023, Game of Thrones was included on The Guardian's list</a>
of worst TV endings of all time.[[288]] Despite the criticism of the writing, the music and visual effects
were praised.[[289][290]]</p>
<p dir="auto">The cast performances were praised throughout the show's run. Peter Dinklage's "charming, morally
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Primetime_Emmy_Award_for_Outstanding_Supporting_Actor_in_a_Drama_Series" rel="nofollow">ambiguous, and self-aware"[[291]] portrayal of Tyrion, which earned him Emmy and Golden Globe awards,</a>
was acclaimed. "In many ways, Game of Thrones belongs to Dinklage", wrote Mary McNamara of the
<em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times" rel="nofollow">Los Angeles Times before Tyrion became the series's central figure in season two.[[292][293]] Several critics</a></em>
highlighted performances by actresses and children.[[292][294]] Lena Headey's portrayal of the "riveting"
Cersei Lannister also received praise.[[291][295]] Maisie Williams was singled out as well and her season
two work with veteran actor Charles Dance (Tywin Lannister).[[296]] Stephen Dillane received positive
reviews for his performance as Stannis Baratheon, especially in the fifth season, with one critic noting
"Whether you like Stannis or not, you have to admit that Stephen Dillane delivered a monumental
performance this season."[[297]] The series was also praised for the portrayal of handicapped and disabled
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dwarf_(mythology)" rel="nofollow">characters.[[298]] One commentator stated that Tyrion Lannister is a "departure from the archetypal dwarf"</a>
often found in other fantasy stories like The Lord of the Rings.[[299]]</p>
<p dir="auto">Darren Franich of Entertainment Weekly gave the series a 'B' rating, saying that it was ultimately "okay".
With both "transcendent moments" and "miserable phases", it was "beloved enough to be criticized by
everyone for something". Franich described seasons three and four as "relentless", seasons six's ending
having a "killer one-two punch", while seasons seven and eight were "indifferent".[[300]] <em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_New_York_Times" rel="nofollow">The New York</a></em></p>
<hr>
<p dir="auto">g g
their lack of complexity and a meandering plot.[[301]] The show, however, appeared on many "best of" lists
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2010s#Television" rel="nofollow">for the end of the 2010s. Alan Sepinwall, writing for Rolling Stone, placed the series on his "50 Best TV</a>
Shows of the 2010s" list, saying its "ability to most of the time keep all of its disparate threads feeling
vital and tied to one another, remains a staggering achievement".[[302]]</p>
<p dir="auto"><strong>Concerns over depiction of sex and violence</strong></p>
<p dir="auto">Despite its otherwise enthusiastic reception by critics, <em>Game of Thrones has been criticized for the</em>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexual_violence" rel="nofollow">amount of female nudity, violence, and sexual violence it depicts, and for the manner in which it depicts</a>
these themes.[[303][304]] George R. R. Martin responded that he felt obliged to be truthful about history and
human nature, and that rape and sexual violence are common in war; and that omitting them from the
narrative would have rung false and undermined one of his novels' themes, its historical realism.[[305]]</p>
<p dir="auto">HBO said that they "fully support the vision and artistry of Dan and David's exceptional work and we feel
this work speaks for itself".[[21]] The show has reportedly been censored or banned for sexual or violent
content in countries like China,[[306][307]] India,[[308][309]] Iran,[[310]] Jordan,[[311]] Singapore,[[312]]</p>
<p dir="auto">Turkey,[[313][314]] United Arab Emirates,[[315]] and Vietnam.[[316]]</p>
<p dir="auto">The amount of sex and nudity in the series, especially in scenes incidental to the plot, was the focus of
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_of_Thrones_season_1" rel="nofollow">much of the criticism aimed at it in its first and second seasons. Stephen Dillane, who portrays Stannis</a>
Baratheon, likened the series's frequent explicit scenes to "German porn from the 1970s".[[317]] The series's
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sexposition" rel="nofollow">use of "sexposition", plot delivery accompanied by sex or nudity, was criticized as distracting.[[318]]</a></p>
<p dir="auto"><em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live" rel="nofollow">Saturday Night Live parodied this aspect of the adaptation in a sketch that portrayed a 13-year-old boy as</a></em>
a Game of Thrones consultant, whose main concern was showing as many breasts as possible.[[319]]</p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Bear_and_the_Maiden_Fair" rel="nofollow">The episode "The Bear and the Maiden Fair" in the third season featured the lengthy torture and eventual</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emasculated" rel="nofollow">emasculation of Theon Greyjoy, which prompted criticism.[[320]]</a> <em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_(magazine)" rel="nofollow">New York magazine called the scene</a></em>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Torture_porn" rel="nofollow">"torture porn".[[321]] According to one commentator, although the series' violence tended to serve a</a>
narrative purpose, Theon's torture in the episode was excessive as well.[[322]] One commentator noted that
Greyjoy's emasculation was one of the few sexual assault scenes where a male was the victim.[[323]] A
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Breaker_of_Chains" rel="nofollow">scene in the fourth season's episode "Breaker of Chains", in which Jaime Lannister rapes his sister and</a>
lover Cersei in the tomb of their dead son, triggered a broad public discussion about the series' depiction
of sexual violence against women. According to Dave Itzkoff of The New York Times, the scene caused
outrage, in part because of comments by director Alex Graves that the scene became "consensual by the
end".[[21]] <em>Game of Thrones has been criticized for adding scenes of rape that were not included in the</em>
novels, such as the rape of Craster's daughters by the mutinous members of the Night's Watch.[[324]] Sonia
Saraiya of <em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_A.V._Club" rel="nofollow">The A.V. Club wrote that the series's choice to portray this sexual act, and a similar one</a></em>
between Daenerys Targaryen and Khal Drogo in the first season—both described as consensual in the
source novels—as a rape appeared to be an act of "exploitation for shock value".[[325]]</p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unbowed,_Unbent,_Unbroken" rel="nofollow">In the fifth season's episode "Unbowed, Unbent, Unbroken", Sansa Stark is raped by Ramsay Bolton.</a>
Most reviewers and publications found the scene gratuitous and artistically unnecessary.[[326][327][328]] In
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Mary_Sue" rel="nofollow">response to the scene, pop culture website The Mary Sue announced that it would cease coverage of the</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Claire_McCaskill" rel="nofollow">series because of the repeated use of rape as a plot device,[[329]] and US Senator Claire McCaskill said that</a>
she would no longer watch it.[[330]] The episode was the lowest rated on Rotten Tomatoes until the season
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Bells_(Game_of_Thrones)" rel="nofollow">eight episode "The Bells".[[331]] As the later seasons saw Daenerys, Sansa, and Cersei assume ruling</a>
positions, Alyssa Rosenberg of <em>The Washington Post noted that the series could be seen as a "long-arc</em></p>
<hr>
<p dir="auto">g y pp p g p
Much of the criticism after the series finale was centered around the handling of the female character
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Male_gaze" rel="nofollow">storylines.[[333]] One commentator cited the male gaze as one of main sources of the "romanticized female</a>
rape" and general nudity throughout the series.[[323]] Another commentator stated the use of both sex and
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Misogyny" rel="nofollow">violence helps perpetuate misogyny within the</a> <em>Game of Thrones universe.[[334]] Sophie Turner, who</em>
portrayed Sansa Stark, has spoken about the long-term impact she believed filming the "heavy" scenes
would have on her and revealed that she developed coping mechanisms to help her through filming.[[335]]</p>
<p dir="auto"><strong>Lighting</strong></p>
<p dir="auto">The lighting, or lack of light, in darker scenes has been a recurring point of criticism since season six of
the series.[[336][337][338][339]] In 2016, <em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bustle_(magazine)" rel="nofollow">Bustle's Caitlyn Callegari listed 31 examples of scenes where the</a></em>
lighting caused viewers problems ranging from not being able to tell a character's hair color to being
unable to see what was going on.[[340]] Some reviewers have noted this is part of a wider trend[[341]] among
shows that are made by people who have experience working primarily on films, suggesting they "haven't
grasped the nuances (or lack thereof)" of television as a medium, especially the differences between
watching a scene on a television screen versus watching it on the big screen in a movie theater.[[342]]</p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_McLachlan_(cinematographer)" rel="nofollow">In a 2017 interview, Robert McLachlan, a cinematographer working on the show, explained the lack of</a>
lighting as an artistic choice saying "we're trying to be as naturalistic as possible".[[343]] The criticism
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Long_Night_(Game_of_Thrones)" rel="nofollow">reached a high point during "The Long Night", the third episode of season eight.[[344][345]] Barely minutes</a>
into the episode, viewers took to social media sites such as Twitter to express their discontent over the
fact that they were having severe difficulties watching the battle and trying to figure out what was going
on.[[346][347]]</p>
<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Cultural influence</h3><a id="user-content-cultural-influence" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Cultural influence" href="#cultural-influence"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<p dir="auto">Although Game of Thrones was initially dismissed by some critics,[[15]] its success has been credited with
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Song_of_Ice_and_Fire#Sales" rel="nofollow">an increase in the fantasy genre's popularity.[[348]] The series's popularity led to increased sales of the</a> <em>A</em>
<em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A_Song_of_Ice_and_Fire#Sales" rel="nofollow">Song of Ice and Fire novels (republished in tie-in editions), which remained at the top of bestseller lists</a></em>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNN" rel="nofollow">for months.[[349][350]] On the eve of the second season's premiere, CNN said, "after this weekend, you may</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epic_fantasy" rel="nofollow">be hard pressed to find someone who isn't a fan of some form of epic fantasy" and cited Ian Bogost as</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Jackson" rel="nofollow">saying that the series continues a trend of successful screen adaptations beginning with Peter Jackson's</a>
<em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings_(film_series)" rel="nofollow">The Lord of the Rings film trilogy (2001–2003) and the</a></em> <em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harry_Potter_(film_series)" rel="nofollow">Harry Potter films (2001–2011) establishing</a></em>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gateway_drugs" rel="nofollow">fantasy as a mass-market genre; they are "gateway drugs to fantasy fan culture".[[351]] The show's success</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Wheel_of_Time_(TV_series)" rel="nofollow">led to the commissioning of several fantasy television series, including The Wheel of Time and The Lord</a>
<em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Lord_of_the_Rings:_The_Rings_of_Power" rel="nofollow">of the Rings: The Rings of Power by Amazon Studios.[[352]] According to Neil Gaiman, whose novels</a></em>
<em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Good_Omens_(TV_series)" rel="nofollow">Good Omens and</a></em> <em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Gods_(TV_series)" rel="nofollow">American Gods were adapted for television,</a></em> <em>Game of Thrones helped to change</em>
attitudes towards fantasy on television, but mainly it made big budgets for fantasy series more
acceptable.[[353]]</p>
<p dir="auto">The success of the genre has been attributed by writers to a longing for escapism in popular culture,
frequent female nudity and a skill in balancing lighthearted and serious topics (dragons and politics, for
example) which provided it with a prestige enjoyed by conventional, top-tier drama series.[[15]] According
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Daily_Beast" rel="nofollow">to The Daily Beast, Game of Thrones was a favorite of sitcom writers and the series has been referred to</a>
in other television series.[[354]] With other fantasy series, it has been cited as a reason for an increase in the
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huskies" rel="nofollow">purchase (and abandonment) of huskies and other wolf-like dogs.[[355]]</a></p>
<hr>
<p dir="auto"><em>f</em> p p y y
explains his motives (or background) while prostitutes have sex in the background gave rise to the word
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exposition_(literary_technique)" rel="nofollow">"sexposition" for providing exposition with sex and nudity.[[356]] Dothraki, the series's nomadic horsemen,</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_Language_Monitor" rel="nofollow">was ranked fourth in a September 2012 Global Language Monitor list of words from television most used</a>
on the internet.[[357]] The series and its characters have also been referenced by politicians and academics
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geopolitics" rel="nofollow">to commentate on modern-day geopolitics, economic inequality, and climate change.[[358][359][360]]</a></p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taylor_Swift" rel="nofollow">In 2019, singer-songwriter Taylor Swift told Entertainment Weekly that several songs on her 2017 album</a>
<em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reputation_(Taylor_Swift_album)" rel="nofollow">Reputation were inspired by Game of Thrones characters and plots.[[361]] "Khaleesi" became more popular</a></em>
as a name for baby girls in the United States. In the novels and the TV series, "khaleesi" is not a name,
but the title of the wife of a "khal" (warlord) in the Dothraki language, held by Daenerys Targaryen.[[362]]</p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daenerys_(given_name)" rel="nofollow">Other names from characters in the series, like Daenerys, also became popular baby names.[[363][364]]</a></p>
<p dir="auto"><em>Game of Thrones has also become a subject of both academic and scientific inquiry.[[365][366]] In 2016,</em>
researchers published a paper analyzing emotional sentiment in online public discourse associated with
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_Association_of_America" rel="nofollow">the unfolding storyline during the fourth season.[[365]] The Mathematical Association of America published</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_science" rel="nofollow">a journal in 2016 that applied the multidisciplinary field of network science to create a social network for</a>
the show's characters and their relationships.[[367]] The analysis purported to be able to distinguish
discussions about an episode's storyline from media critiques or assessments of a specific actor's
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Survival_analysis" rel="nofollow">performance. In 2018, Australian scientists conducted a survival analysis and examined the mortality</a>
among 330 important characters during the first seven seasons of <em>Game of Thrones.[[32]] In 2019, the</em>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australian_Red_Cross" rel="nofollow">Australian Red Cross conducted a study using international humanitarian law to determine which of the</a>
<em>Game of Thrones</em> <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/War_crime" rel="nofollow">' characters had committed the most war crimes during the first seven seasons of the</a>
show.[[368][369]]</p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kinorhyncha" rel="nofollow">Animals have also been named after the show. Three species of mud dragons; Echinoderes daenerysae,</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bombyliidae" rel="nofollow">Echinoderes rhaegal and Echinoderes drogoni,[[370]] a bee fly; Paramonovius nightking,[[371]] three species</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scarabaeidae" rel="nofollow">of scarab beetles; Gymnetis drogoni, Gymnetis rhaegali and Gymnetis viserioni,[[372]] and a brittle star,</a>
Ophiohamus georgemartini, due to its sharp thorns resembling those depicted on the <em>Game of Thrones</em>
crown.[[373]]</p>
<p dir="auto"><em>Game of Thrones episode recap articles were a significant source of web traffic for many top news sites,</em>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Atlantic" rel="nofollow">including The Atlantic, The New York Times and NPR.[[374]]</a></p>

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Awards</h3><a id="user-content-awards" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Awards" href="#awards"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<p dir="auto"><em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Screen_Actors_Guild_Award" rel="nofollow">Game of Thrones has won numerous awards throughout its run, including 59 Emmy Awards, eight Screen</a></em>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Screen_Actors_Guild_Award" rel="nofollow">Actors Guild Awards and a Peabody Award. It holds the record for total Emmy Award wins for a scripted</a>
television series (surpassing the record of 37 wins held by <em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frasier" rel="nofollow">Frasier since 2004) and for most Emmy</a></em>
nominations for a drama series, with 161.[[153][387][388][389]] In 2019, the show's final season established a
new record for most Emmy nominations received in a year with 32, breaking the 25-year-long record of
26 nominations established by <em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NYPD_Blue" rel="nofollow">NYPD Blue in 1994.[[390]] In 2013, the Writers Guild of America listed</a></em>
<em>Game of Thrones as the 40th best written series in television history.[[391]] Also in 2013, at the Media</em>
Access Awards, George R. R. Martin accepted the Visionary Award from the Writers With Disabilities
committee of the Writers Guild of America, for its positive portrayal of character with disabilities.[[392]] In
2015, <em>The Hollywood Reporter placed it at number four on their best TV shows ever list,[[393]] while in</em>
2016 the series was placed seventh on <em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empire_(magazine)" rel="nofollow">Empire's "The 50 best TV shows ever".[[394]] The same year,</a></em>
<em>Rolling Stone named it the twelfth "greatest TV Show of all time".[[395]] In 2023, Variety ranked Game of</em>
<em>Thrones No. 21 on its list of the 100 greatest TV shows of all time.[[396]]</em></p>
<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Viewership</h3><a id="user-content-viewership" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Viewership" href="#viewership"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<p dir="auto"><em>Game of Thrones was considered a ratings success for HBO throughout all eight seasons.[[397][398]] The</em>
show premiere was watched by 2.2 million, and the first season averaged 2.5 million viewers per
episode.[[399]] For its second season, the series had an average gross audience of 11.6 million viewers.[[400]]</p>
<p dir="auto">The third season was seen by 14.2 million viewers, making <em>Game of Thrones the second-most-viewed</em>
HBO series (after <em>The Sopranos).[[401]] HBO said that</em> <em>Game of Thrones' average gross audience of</em>
18.4 million viewers (later adjusted to 18.6 million) had passed <em>The Sopranos for the viewership</em>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_House_of_Black_and_White" rel="nofollow">record.[[402][403]] The season five episode "The House of Black and White" was simulcasted in 173</a>
countries, becoming the "largest TV drama telecast" according to Guinness World Records.[[404]]</p>
<hr>
<p dir="auto">y g p p g g g
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Times" rel="nofollow">nearly 40 percent of viewers watching on HBO digital platforms.[[405]] In 2016, a New York Times study of</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facebook_like" rel="nofollow">the 50 TV shows with the most Facebook likes found that Game of Thrones was "much more popular in</a>
cities than in the countryside, probably the only show involving zombies that is".[[406]] By season seven,
the average viewer numbers had grown to 32.8 million per episode across all platforms.[[407][408]] The
series finale was viewed by 19.3 million people across HBO's platforms, becoming the network's most
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hammocking" rel="nofollow">watched episode.[[409][410]] The lead-out show also benefited from the finale's record viewership.[[411]]</a></p>
<p dir="auto"><em>Game of Thrones also set viewership records outside the United States on pay-television channels in the</em>
United Kingdom (with a 2016 average audience of more than five million on all platforms)[[412]] and
Australia (with a cumulative average audience of 1.2 million).[[413]] Video streaming research company
Parrot Analytics stated that after the US, the season eight premiere demand was "particularly strong in the
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nielsen_Media_Research" rel="nofollow">United Kingdom and France".[[414]] Nielsen Media Research noted the show was popular among 18 to 49</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Key_demographic" rel="nofollow">key demographic with strong female viewership for a fantasy series.[[415][416]] The show also benefited</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_shifting" rel="nofollow">from time shifting viewership. Between season one and season seven, 7-day viewers, the number of both</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_video_recorder" rel="nofollow">DVR and video on demand views during the week after the episode broadcast, grew from 3.3 million to</a>
13.7 million.[[417]] Following the show finale, commentators said many viewers might cancel their
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WarnerMedia" rel="nofollow">premium television and streaming subscriptions.[[418]] HBO parent company WarnerMedia reported that</a>
subscription revenue declined only 0.9 percent between April and June 2019.[[419]]</p>

<p dir="auto"><em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thronecast" rel="nofollow">Thronecast: The Official Guide to Game of Thrones, a series of podcasts presented by Geoff Lloyd and</a></em>
produced by Koink, were released on the Sky Atlantic website and the UK iTunes store during the series's
run; a new podcast, with analysis and cast interviews, was released after each episode.[[429]] In 2014 and
2015, HBO commissioned <em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catch_the_Throne" rel="nofollow">Catch the Throne, two rap albums about the series.[[430][431]] A companion</a></em>
book, Inside HBO's Game of Thrones by series writer Bryan Cogman, was published on September 27,
2012. The 192-page book, illustrated with concept art and behind-the-scenes photographs, covers the
creation of the series's first two seasons and its principal characters and families.[[432]]</p>

<p dir="auto"><em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/After_the_Thrones" rel="nofollow">After the Thrones was a live aftershow during which hosts Andy Greenwald and Chris Ryan discussed</a></em>
episodes of the series. It aired on <em>HBO Now, the Monday following each season six episode.[[433]] The</em>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_of_Thrones_Live_Concert_Experience" rel="nofollow">Game of Thrones Live Concert Experience, a North American 28-city orchestral tour which performed</a>
the series's soundtrack with composer Ramin Djawadi, began in February 2017 and concluded in April
2017.[[434][435]] A second tour followed in 2018 across cities in Europe and North America.[[436]]</p>

<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Still_motion" rel="nofollow">Each season's Blu-ray and DVD set contains several short still motion animated sequences titled</a>
<em>Histories and Lore, narrated by the cast, in character, as they detail events in the history of Westeros.[[437]]</em></p>
<p dir="auto">For the seventh season, this was to include the animated prequel series <em>Game of Thrones: Conquest &amp;</em>
<em>Rebellion, illustrated in a different animation style than previous videos. The series focuses on Aegon</em>
Targaryen's conquest of the Seven Kingdoms of Westeros.[[438]] A week after the series finale, HBO
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_of_Thrones:_The_Last_Watch" rel="nofollow">released a behind-the-scenes documentary entitled Game of Thrones: The Last Watch.[[439]] The program</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Read-through" rel="nofollow">documented the production of season 8 along with read-throughs and interviews with the cast.[[440]]</a></p>
<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Successors</h3><a id="user-content-successors" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Successors" href="#successors"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<hr>
<p dir="auto">y y p p
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_Borenstein" rel="nofollow">Borenstein, Jane Goldman, Brian Helgeland, Carly Wray, and Bryan Cogman to develop five individual</a>
<em>Game of Thrones successor series;[[441]] the writers were to be working individually with</em>
George R. R. Martin, who also co-wrote two of the scripts.[[442]] D. B. Weiss and David Benioff said that
they would not be involved with any of the projects.[[443]]</p>
<p dir="auto">Martin said that all the concepts under discussion were prequels, although he believes the term "successor
show" applies better to these projects, as they are not Game of Thrones spin-offs in the traditional sense.
He ruled out Robert's Rebellion (the overthrow of Daenerys's father by Robert Baratheon) as a possible
idea and revealed that some may be set outside Westeros.[[444]] In September 2018, speaking about the four
projects (i.e. not about Goldman's project), HBO president of programming Casey Bloys said that some
of them had been abandoned completely, while others remained as possibilities for the future;[[445]] Martin
said that: "at least two of them are solidly based on material in Fire &amp; Blood".[[446]] In May 2019, Martin
stated that two of the projects were still in the script stage, but were "edging closer".[[447]] In April 2019,
Cogman confirmed his prequel would not be moving forward.[[448]]</p>
<p dir="auto"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adult_animation" rel="nofollow">In January 2021, an adult animated spin-off series was announced to be in development at HBO Max.[[449]]</a></p>
<p dir="auto">In July 2021, two more animated series were in development at HBO Max, with one being set in Yi Ti, a
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imperial_China" rel="nofollow">nation in Essos loosely based on Imperial China.[[450]] The working title is The Golden Empire.[[451]]</a></p>
<p dir="auto">In March 2021, it was reported that three Game of Thrones spin-offs were in development at HBO; they
include 10,000 Ships (from Amanda Segal), a reference to the voyages made by warrior queen Princess
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bruno_Heller" rel="nofollow">Nymeria, who later founds Dorne; 9 Voyages aka The Sea Snake (from Bruno Heller), about the voyages</a>
of Corlys Velaryon on his vessel the Sea Snake; and a project based on Flea Bottom, the poorest slum in
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jon_Snow_(character)" rel="nofollow">King's Landing.[[452][453]] In June 2022, it was reported that a Jon Snow sequel series with Kit Harington</a>
to reprise his role was in early development at HBO.[[454]] The working title was <em>Snow and Martin</em>
confirmed his involvement with the project and that Harington initiated the idea.[[453]] In April 2024,
however, Harington stated the show had been shelved because they could not find a story that excited
them enough.[[455]] In April 2023, it was reported that a series based on Aegon Targaryen's conquest of
Westeros was in development.[[456]] In December 2023, it was announced that <em>The Sea Snake is being</em>
developed as an animated series, having been previously announced as a live action series.[[457]]</p>
<p dir="auto"><strong><em>Bloodmoon</em></strong></p>
<p dir="auto">On June 8, 2018, HBO commissioned a pilot to a <em>Game of Thrones prequel series from Goldman as</em>
showrunner and Martin as co-creator.[[458]] The prequel was to take place in the Age of Heroes, a period
that begins roughly 10,000 years before the events of <em>Game of Thrones. Notable events of that period</em>
include the foundation of powerful Houses, the Long Night when the White Walkers first descended upon
Westeros, and the Andal Invasion when the Andals invaded from Essos and conquered most of
Westeros.[[459]] Martin suggested <em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S._J._Clarkson" rel="nofollow">The Long Night as a title for the series.[[460]] S. J. Clarkson was</a></em>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naomi_Watts" rel="nofollow">announced to direct and executive produce the pilot,[[461]] while Naomi Watts was cast as the female lead</a>
playing "a charismatic socialite hiding a dark secret".[[462]] Other series regulars were to include: Josh
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toby_Regbo" rel="nofollow">Whitehouse, Toby Regbo, Ivanno Jeremiah, Georgie Henley, Naomi Ackie, Denise Gough, Jamie</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jamie_Campbell_Bower" rel="nofollow">Campbell Bower, Sheila Atim, Alex Sharp, Miranda Richardson, Marquis Rodriguez, John Simm,</a></p>
<hr>
<p dir="auto">,, g p, p
was in post-production[[464]] but in October 2019, it was announced that HBO had decided not to move
forward with the series.[[465]]</p>
<p dir="auto"><strong><em>House of the Dragon</em></strong></p>
<p dir="auto">In September 2019, <em><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deadline_Hollywood" rel="nofollow">Deadline Hollywood reported that a second prequel from Martin and Ryan Condal</a></em>
that "tracks the beginning of the end for House Targaryen" was close to receiving a pilot order from
HBO; the project is not considered an original sixth script, as it builds upon Cogman's idea from
2017.[[466]] This prequel, titled House of the Dragon, was commissioned as a complete series on October
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fire_%26_Blood_(novel)" rel="nofollow">29, 2019. The 10-episode series is to be based on material from Fire and Blood, executive produced by</a>
Martin, Vince Gerardis, Condal, and Miguel Sapochnik; the latter two are to be its showrunners as
well.[[467]] In January 2020, HBO stated that the series is scheduled for a 2022 release and that the writing
process has begun.[[468]] Casting for the series started in July 2020.[[469]] In October 2020, it was revealed
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paddy_Considine" rel="nofollow">that Paddy Considine was cast as King Viserys I Targaryen.[[470]] In December 2020, three more castings</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olivia_Cooke" rel="nofollow">were announced: Olivia Cooke as Alicent Hightower, Emma D'Arcy as Rhaenyra Targaryen, and Matt</a>
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matt_Smith" rel="nofollow">Smith as Daemon Targaryen.[[471]] In February 2021, HBO chief content officer Casey Bloys stated that</a>
the show would start production in April, with filming occurring in England.[[472][473]] In February 2021,
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Toussaint" rel="nofollow">Steve Toussaint, Eve Best, Rhys Ifans, and Sonoya Mizuno were confirmed to also be starring in the</a>
series.[[474]] In March 2022, HBO announced a series premiere date of August 21, 2022, followed by the
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teaser_(trailer)" rel="nofollow">release of the official teaser trailer.[[475]]</a></p>
<p dir="auto"><strong><em>A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms</em></strong></p>
<p dir="auto">In January 2021, it was revealed that HBO were developing another prequel series to be based on
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tales_of_Dunk_and_Egg" rel="nofollow">Martin's novella series Tales of Dunk and Egg.[[476]] Steven Conrad was attached as writer and executive</a>
producer of the <em>Tales of Dunk and Egg series in November 2021.[[477]] In April 2023, HBO ordered</em> <em>A</em>
<em>Knight of the Seven Kingdoms to series.[[478]]</em></p>
